Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 800.00 ($ 268.00), el cual será pagado en 6 cuotas, comprará la materia prima para la elaboración de sus bocaditos como son harina de trigo (01 saco), harina de maíz (01 saco), azúcar (01 saco), mantequilla (10 kg.), plátano maduro (02 racimos), quesos (05 kg.), maní (05 kg.) y otros productos más que complementen la preparación de sus bocaditos.

Ella está casada, tiene 48 años y tiene 02 hijos, quienes ya no dependen económicamente de ella y su esposo. Se considera muy dedicada y empeñosa con su trabajo, organizada y responsable.

loans.use: Buy raw ingredients for food business.

loans.name: Yolith

texts.es:
Yolith belongs to the Corazon D. Jesus ("Jesus Heart") community bank. Her business is in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She earns a living selling general merchandise and "chicha D. maiz" (a weak alcoholic drink), which she sells to local people, most of whom are agricultural workers, and to visitors who want to enjoy a local drink.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.500 (500 Peruvian soles or about US$167) to be repaid in 4 installments, Yolith will buy bulk supplies of rice, sugar, egs, cookies, soap, detergent, toilet paper and other products.

Yolith, 63 is married and has 3 children, all of whom are independent. At her age, she's happy that she's able to give the best of herself to her family and her business. She's pleased, too, that she's able to contribute to household expenses and that she can share a tranquil life with her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Yolith pertenece al Banco Comunal Corazón D. Jesús, tiene ubicado su negocio en el Barrio San Isidro – Carretera a Shatoja en la Localidad D. San José D. Sisa, provincia D. El Dorado, Departamento D. San Martín. Ella se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes y también D. chicha D. maíz (bebida ligera), la cual es vendida a los pobladores que se dedican principalmente al trabajo agrícola y visitantes que les gusta disfrutar D. esta bebida regional.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 500.00 ($ 167.00), el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más productos como: arroz y azúcar en sacos (01 saco D. cada uno), huevos (02 casilleros), galletas (02 cajas, entre dulces y saladas), jabones (1/2 caja D. cada marca), detergentes D. diferentes marcas, papel higiénico (02 paquetes); y otros productos.

Ella está casada, tiene 63 años y tiene 03 hijos, pero todos ya son independientes. A su edad se siente muy contenta ya que da lo mejor D. ella para su familia y su negocio, se siente satisfecha D. poder aportar en los gastos del hogar y poder compartir junto a su esposo una vida tranquila.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

location.town: San José de Sisa - San Martin

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es:
Hermelinda belongs to the Corazon de Jesus ("Jesus Heart") community bank. Her business is located in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She sells general merchandise and helps her husband operate a "ladrillaria" (brick sales) business.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.500 (500 Peruvian soles or about US$167), to be repaid in 4 installments, Hermelinda will buy bulk supplies of pasta; fish preserves; rice; sugar; cooking oil; soap; shampoo; vegetables--potatoes, onions, tomatoes; and seasonal fruits.

Hermelinda, 37, has 2 children who are still in school and who support her by helping around the house. She works at the brick-selling business because her husband's health is poor but also because she realized that she liked doing it. Hermelinda is a happy woman, hard-working, persistent and dedicated to her work.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Hermelinda del Banco Comunal Corazón de Jesús, tiene ubicado su negocio en el Barrio San Isidro – Carretera a Shatoja en la Localidad de San José de Sisa, provincia de El Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, además de apoyar a su esposo en la administración de la ladrillaría (venta de ladrillos).

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500.00 ($ 167.00), el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará fideos de distintas variedades y marcas (04 paquetes), conservas de pescado (04 cajas), arroz y azúcar en sacos (01 sacos de cada producto), aceite en galón (para su venta al menudeo) y en litros, jabón (02 cajas de diferente marca), 02 cajas de shampoo en saches, algunas verduras: como papa, cebolla, tomate (5 kg. de cada uno) y frutas, dependiendo de la época.

Ella tiene 37 años de edad y 2 hijas que aun están estudiando en el colegio y quienes le apoyan con las actividades del hogar. El motivo por el que se está dedicando a la ladrillaría es que su esposo se encuentra delicado de salud y además se dio cuenta que es una actividad que le gusta. Se siente muy contenta, ella se caracteriza por ser trabajadora, perseverante y responsable con sus labores.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

location.town: San José de Sisa - San Martin

loans.name: Nilda Angelica

texts.es:
Nilda belongs to the Las Riojanitas ("The Rioja Girls") community bank. The business is located in her house in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She earns a living selling hats and decorative objects made from "paja tratada de bomonaje" (a treated straw commonly used for making hats). Nilda is glad to be able to work with local products and to support a local craft.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.2,000 (2,000 Peruvian soles or about US$670), to be repaid in 6 installments, Nilda will buy 20 rolls of treated bomonaje straw, 5 rolls of cloth ribbon of different colors, and other products for making and finishing her straw hats.

Nilda, 50, is married and has 3 grown children who help her with household expenses as her husband's health is poor. She's very happy for the opportunity to work and that there's support for women to work.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Nilda pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Riojanitas, tiene ubicado su negocio en su casa ubicada en el Jr. Amargura 1132 del distrito de Rioja, provincia de Rioja, Departamento de San Martín. Ella se dedica a la venta de sombreros de paja tratada de bombonaje y adornos elaborados del mismo material. Ella se siente muy feliz de poder trabajar con un producto de la zona e incentivar la artesanía.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,000.00 ($ 670.00), el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará materia prima (paja de bombonaje previamente tratada) por un total de 20 rollos, cinta de tela (05 rollos de diferentes colores), 10 docenas de adornos y otros productos complementarios para la elaboración y acabado de las artesanías.

Ella está casada, tiene 50 años y tiene 03 hijos, todos mayores de edad, que le apoyan en el sustento de su hogar debido a que tiene a su esposo delicado de salud. Se siente muy feliz por el trabajo que desarrolla y así fomentar el trabajo en las mujeres.

loans.use: Buy bulk supplies of straw, ribbon, and cloth for hat-making business.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira belongs to the Las Riojanitas ("The Rioja Girls") community bank. Her business is located in her house in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She offers hair-dressing services (haricuts, waves, coloring, etc.) and sells beauty products.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.500 (500 Peruvian soles or about US$167), to be repaid in 4 installments, Elvira will buy supplies like hair dyes (24 units of different colors), luminous base (2 litres), "acidos fijadores" (2 litres), shampoos and conditioners.

Elvira is a single mother. Her children were her main motivator for starting the business. She's proud that she's independent and that she's managed to set up the business at home. She also shares her knowledge, teaching what she most enjoys--hair-dressing--at a local vocational school.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman

La señora Elvira pertenece al Banco Comunal las Riojanitas, tiene ubicado su negocio en su casa en el Jr. Angaiza 735 del distrito de Rioja, provincia de Rioja, Departamento de San Martín. Ella brinda servicios de cosmetología (corte de cabello, ondulaciones, tintes y otros) así mismo a la venta de productos de cosmetología.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500.00 ($ 167.00), el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará materiales como tintes para cabello (24 unidades de distintos colores), bases luminosas (02 litros), ácidos fijadores (02 litros), shampoos y acondicionadores de cabello (02 litros).

Ella es madre soltera, sus hijos son su principal razón para salir adelante y se siente muy orgullosa porque ahora es independiente y se organiza para distribuir las tareas en el hogar. Comparte sus actividades de docente en un Centro Ocupacional enseñando lo que más le gusta hacer... cosmetología.

loans.use: Buy products for beauty salon.

loans.name: Liciola Del Carmen

texts.es:
Luciola belongs to the Las Riojanitas ("The Rioja Girls") community bank. Her business is located in her house in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She sells "maduritos asados" (aged meats) filled with cheese and mani (made from platanos). She also sells beauty products. Because of her physical disability, she can't easily go out so her customers come to her.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (1,000 Peruvian soles or about US$335), to be repaid in 6 installments, Luciola will buy ingredients for making "maduritos asados" like mani (10 kg., cheese (10 kg) and 5 bunches of platanos. She will also buy beauty products so that she has them in stock for her customers.

Luciola, 50, is married and has 2 grown children with families of their own. She's proud of the work that she's doggedly pursued because her customers are happy. Furthermore, she's proud of being a strong example of determination and perserverance.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Luciola pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Riojanitas, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su casa, en el Jr. Amagura 1128 del distrito de Rioja, provincia de Rioja, Departamento de San Martín. Ella se dedica a la venta de maduritos asados rellenos con queso y maní (elaborado a base de plátanos), además de vender productos de belleza, ya que por su discapacidad física n puede movilizarse mucho a otros lugares y son los clientes la que la visitan.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000.00 ($ 335.00), el cual será pagado en 6 cuotas, comprará materia prima para la elaboración de maduritos asados como por ejemplo: maní (10 kg.), queso (10 kg.), 05 racimos de plátano maduro. Además comprará productos de belleza para tener en stock cuando su clientela la visite.

Ella está casada, tiene 50 años y tiene 02 hijos, mayores de edad que tiene ya su familia conformada, se siente muy orgullosa del trabajo que desempeña porque su clientela se siente satisfecha, además de ser un claro ejemplo de lucha y perseverancia.

loans.use: Compra de insumos.  Compra de productos de belleza.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa belongs to the Corazon de Jesus (Jesus Heart) community bank. Her business is located in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She makes a living selling general merchandise, fruits and fresh vegetables; she also makes and sells snacks, like pastries made from yucca starch and sweets made with wheat and corn flour, that are in much demand from her customers. She's been working at the business for 20 years. During all that time, too, she's been selling local drink favorites such as "chicha de maiz" (a corn-based liquor) and "mazato"

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.500 (500 Peruvian soles or about US$167), to be repaid in 4 months, Luisa will buy bulk supplies of rice, sugar, candy, eggs, cookies, soap, and detergent.

Luisa, 58, is married and has 3 children, the oldest of whom is independent. The second, a boy, studies at the university in Lima and the youngest is still in a local school. Luisa is very hard-working and persistent. She's driven by the satisfaction of being able to help with household expenses and support her husband when something unforeseen affects the family.

Translated by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Luisa pertenece al Banco Comunal Corazón de Jesús, tiene ubicado su negocio en la Localidad de San José de Sisa, provincia de El Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, frutas y verduras frescas; además complementa su negocio con la producción de bocaditos como son las rosquitas de almidón de yuca y otros dulce de harina de trigo y maíz, que son muy requeridos por sus clientes; se dedica a esta actividad desde hace 20 años. Paralelamente se dedica a la venta de bebidas regionales como la chicha de maíz y el mazato (bebidas de la zona).

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500.00 ($ 167.00), el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará más productos como: arroz y azúcar en sacos (01 saco de cada producto), muchas golosinas en paquetes (08 paquetes de diferentes productos), huevos en jabas (02 casilleros), galletas (02 cajas, entre dulces y saladas), jabones (1/2 caja de cada marca), detergentes de diferentes marcas.

Ella está casada, tiene 58 años y tiene 03 hijos, la mayor ya es independiente, el segundo es varón y estudia en la universidad en la ciudad de Lima, la ultima aun está en la escuela. La señora Luisa se caracteriza por ser muy trabajadora y empeñosa en sus actividades, lo que le impulsa es la satisfacción de poder contribuir en los gastos de su hogar y ser un respaldo para su esposo cuando se presente algún imprevisto en la familia.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

location.town: San José de Sisa - San Martin

loans.name: Teolith

texts.es:
Teolith belongs to the Mujeres Valerosas II ("Valiant Women II") community bank. She lives in Peru's San Martin region. She provides sewing services to the general public. Her husband helped her to start the business. Carrying out the work requires a temporary employee (in the busy season). Loans from Manuela Ramos have allowed Teolith to buy miscellaneous sewing supplies (threads, buttons, snaps, etc.), as well as cloth, because most of her orders are only for sewing and her customers provide the cloth for the outfits she makes.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.500 (500 Peruvian soles or about US$167), to be repaid in 4 months, Teolith bought cloth by the meter (at wholesale), buttons, snaps and other sewing supplies.

Teolith, 55, lives with her husband and their 2 children. In the future, she'd like to have her own dress shop in a local market with outfits she makes herself. She's very pleased with what she's been able to do because thanks to this business, she's been able to send her children to school.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Teolith pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas II”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, con domicilio en el Jr. Manuel Arévalo Orbe Nº 344. La señora Teolith brinda servicio de costura al público en general. Para iniciar su negocio tuvo el apoyo de su esposo. Para realizar los trabajos encomendados requiere de un personal en forma eventual (temporada alta). El apoyo de Manuela Ramos por medio de los préstamos, le ha permitido comprar artículos de pasamanería (hilos, botones, cierres y otros para los acabados) asimismo compró tela para confeccionar ya que la mayor parte de su servicio es sólo servicio de costura y el cliente entrega la tela.

Con el reciente crédito recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500.00 ($ 167.00), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compró telas por metros (al por mayor), botones, cierres, y otros artículos de pasamanería.

La señora Teolith, tiene 55 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos, en adelante piensa tener su tienda de venta de vestidos que ella misma confecciona en el mercado de esta localidad. Ella está contenta con lo que hace ya que gracias a esto puede hacer estudiar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy supplies for tailoring business.

loans.name: Neris Del Socorro

texts.es:
Mrs.Neris has a plantain selling business, she buys harvests and sells them wholesale and retail. She started 10 years ago with an initial capital of C$10,000 (cordobas), money that she had saved for many years. Before starting her own business, she worked during the harvesting seasons providing manual labor to collect the fruits and vegetables that are grown in the region.

She started by delivering the vegetable harvests to all the sellers in the Managua and Chinandega markets, but decided to rent her own stand in the market and invest in buying plantains to sell retail.

Thanks to her initiative and excellent work with the credits (approximately 47 credits) that she has been granted, she and her family have managed to get ahead, improved their quality of life, and bought more products of higher quality. It hasn’t been easy so far and she is conscious of the hard work needed to get to the finish line but she hopes to always count on the help of those that offer it.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Neris tiene una venta de platanos, compra por cosecha y vende al por mayor y al detalle. Inició hace 10 años con un capital inicial de C$ 10,000 (diez mil cordobas netos), dinero que tenia ahorrado por muchos años. Antes de tener este negocio ella trabajaba en las temporadas de cosecha, en los cultivos dando su mano de obra para colectar las frutas y verduras que cultivan en esta zona.

Inició entregando produccion de verduras a todos los vendedores del mercado de Managua y Chinandega, pero decidió alquilar un tramo en el mercado e invertir comprando platanos para venderlos al detalle.

Gracias a esta iniciativa y la buena manera de trabajar con los créditos (aproximadamente 47 créditos) que se le han otorgado, ella y su familia han logrado salir adelante, mejorando su nivel de vida, ha comprado mas productos y de mayor calidad....recuerda que llegar a donde está no ha sido facil y esta conciente que para llegar a la meta necesita de mucho esfuerzo esperando contar siempre con la ayuda de quienes se la brinda.

loans.use: To buy products like plantains and other vegetables to sell retail.

loans.name: Josefa Vicenta

texts.es:
Josefa has a business selling fruits and vegetables such as pomegranates, rambutans (a relative of lychee), oranges, and other produce, buying in bulk and selling individually. She has worked in this business for more than 12 years, and she started by investing her savings (at that time C$2000 cordobas), traveling to Masaya to buy the fruit and selling it in the street as a walking vendor with a basket on her head.

Prior to becoming a fruit and vegetable vendor, Josefa worked as a maid, but she told us that she was unable to maintain her young son with the salary that she earned. For that reason she thought seriously about better options, and after selling on the street she succeeded in saving enough money so that, along with her first loan, she was able to rent a module. The module does not provide the ideal conditions to give her business a good presentation for her clients, but Josefa is determined to work hard in order to refinish and make the location beautiful so that her clients will be attracted to buy there.

Josefa is a single mother who is happy to see that her son has done well in his studies. She is satisfied because she feels confident that her economic situation is getting better and her child will be able to attend the university. She is hopeful that through loans she will be able to reach a better quality of life, and her business capital will grow little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Josefa tiene un negocio de ventas de frutas y verduras, tales como Granadilla, Mamon Chino, Naranja entre otros, comprando a los mayoristas y vendiendo al detalle. Lleva mas de 12 años trabajando con este negocio que lo inició invirtiendo sus ahorros (en ese momento C$2000, dos mil cordobas), viajando a masaya a comprar las frutas y hacer sus ventas en la calle caminando con una canasta sobre su cabeza.

Antes de dedicarse a vender las frutas y verduras su trabajo era de empleada doméstica, pero nos comenta que no podia mantener a su pequeño niño con el salario que le daban. Así que seriamente pensó en superarse y despues de vender en las calles logró recoger algo de dinero mas su primer crédito que le permitió adquirir un módulo alquilado, actualmente este no cuenta con las condiciones ideales para tener buena presentacion ante sus clientes, pero esta decidida a trabajar bastante para lograr construir y dejar bien bonito este local para que los clientes se vean atraidos a comprarle.

Ella es una madre soltera que se siente feliz de ver como su hijo ha logrado mucho con sus estudios y esta satisfecha porque confia en que la situacion economica irá mejorando y así su niño pordra ir a la universidad. Se siente feliz porque con los créditos a logrado tener un mejor nivel de vida que antes, y su capital de trabajo va aumentando poco a poco.

loans.use: To buy fresh fruits and vegetables in order to sell them to customers

loans.name: Yasenem

texts.ru:
Mrs. Yasenem K. lives in a village near Saatli, Azerbaijan. She is 42, married and has 2 children. She and her brother (see photo) have an electronics store. The business goes well and Mrs. K. wants to expand it. To finance the expansion, she applied for a loan from NorMicro, a Kiva partner.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Г-жа Ясенем живет в деревне, расположенной около города Саатлы Республики Азербайджан. Ей 42 года, замужем, имеет двоих детей. Она вместе со своим братом (см. фото) содержат магазин, где продают электронные и электрические товары. Торговля идет хорошо, и поэтому Ясенем решила взять кредит для расширения бизвеса и обратилась за помощью к Норвежскому Микрокредиту-партнеру КИВА.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: I am Shazia I. from the small city of Arifwala, Pakistan. I am 24, married, and the mother of two daughters. They are not of school-going age yet; but when they are, I will surely send them to school. My husband is a rickshaw (local three-wheeled taxi) driver. I sew clothes on order. At present, my husband drives someone else's rickshaw on rent. Now he wants to buy his own, for which we require a loan. This way we will not have to pay for rent any more, and we will build an asset of our own.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Melek

texts.en:
Melek is a vulnerable, low-income person. She is 47 and married with four children and lives in the village of Saatli in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan in the Caucasus region.

Melek owns a herd of milk cows. Every day she sells milk to the local milk processing shop. Her children help her to care for the cows. The income from four cows is too low to support the family and to increase her number of cows. That’s why Melek applied to Norwegian Microcredit's Saatli branch for a $500 loan to buy one more purebred cow to make her monthly income higher. The price of a milk calf is $300, and the cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 she plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

loans.name: Aslan

texts.en: Mr. K. is a vulnerable, low-income person. He is 34 and married with two children and lives in Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan in the Caucasus region. Aslan has owned and operated a small food market in the local bazaar of Saatli town for 10 years. The business is stable because Aslan has earned return customers during the time he has run this shop. However, there is no capital to diversify the inventory and increase the turnover, and thereby increase the income to provide all the necessities of life of his children. Some commercial banks demand collateral to give to Aslan credit, but Aslan has nothing to mortgage. That's why he applied to Normicro's Saatli branch, which disburses credit free of collateral, for a $500 loan. This credit would enable him to buy and sell a larger amount of goods and to develop his business.

loans.use: To increase the variety of his inventory

loans.name: Ilkham

texts.en: Mr. K. is a vulnerable, low-income person. He is 35 and married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan in the Caucasus region. Ilkham owns and operates a mini shop in Saatli town. He sells spare parts, oil and other items for cars. However, his working capital is very limited and he has no opportunity to diversify his inventory. For this purpose, he has applied to Normicro's Saatli branch and is waiting to receive a $500 loan.

loans.use: To increase variety in his inventory

loans.name: Arzu

texts.ru:
Mrs. Arzu M. lives in a village near Saatli, Azerbaijan. She is 40, married and has 3 children. Five years ago, Mrs. M. and her husband (see photo) opened a fuel store. The business goes well, but for safety it requires periodic maintenance and equipment replacement. To finance the renovation, Mrs. Arzu M. applied for a loan from NorMicro, a Kiva partner.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Г-жа Арзу живет в деревне, расположенной около города Саатлы Республики Азербайджан. Ей 40 лет, замужем, имеет троих детей. Пять лет тому назад она вместе со своим мужем (см. фото) открыла газозаправочную станцию. Торговля пошла хорошо, но этот вид бизнеса требует время от времени обновления оборудования в целях безопасности.Для этой цели Манзар решила взять кредит и обратилась за помощью к Норвежскому Микрокредиту-партнеру КИВА.

loans.use: Renovation and safety equipment replacement

loans.name: Ilkhama

texts.ru:
Mrs. Ilkhama M. lives in a village located near the city of Saatli, Azerbaijan. She is 40, married and has 3 children. Five years ago, Mrs. M. together with her husband (shown on the photo) purchased a small number of chickens, raised them and then sold them at the local market. The sale went well and brought a sizable profit. In addition, Ilkhama was able to sell and use the eggs that chickens produced. To finance expansion of her successful business, Ilkhama applied for a loan from NorMicro, a Kiva partner.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Г-жа Илхама живет в деревне, расположенной около города Саатлы Республики Азербайджан. Ей 40 лет, замужем, имеет троих детей. Пять лет тому назад она вместе со своим мужем (см. фото) купила небольшое количество цыплят, вырастила их и продала на местном базаре. Торговля пошла хорошо, прибыль была ощутимой. Кроме того, Илхама могла использивать для продажи и потребления яйца, которые несли куры. Успешный бизнес требовал расширения. С этой цели Илхама решила взять кредит и обратилась за помощью к Норвежскому Микрокредиту-партнеру КИВА.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Uzma

texts.en: My husband is very ambitious to improve our living standard. He runs a small mobile phones store. His store has been growing gradually since inception. Mobile phones have become a necessity and a rapid form of communication these days. Therefore, due an increased demand for these phones, my husband wishes to expand the range of mobiles at his store for which he requires a loan of $250. He wants to develop a strong client base so that he can increase his earnings. We hope to have a prosperous future with all the luxuries of life for us.

loans.use: Buy an extended range of mobiles for my husband's store.

loans.name: Azer

texts.en:
Azer A. is 37-year-old father of two children. He is from the Armenian conflict territory of Lachin, situated in the west part of Azerbaijan. Right now he lives in the city of Sumgayit with his family. He is the only breadwinner of his family. He is a low-income farmer who is very vulnerable to shifts in the local economy. He started his business in 2001, when he purchased two sheep with money he had saved up. In 2005, Azer borrowed $500 to add to his own savings of $250 and purchased another sheep. Since January 2006, prices have doubled, and Azer applied for a loan of $800 from Normicro, purchased two calves for meat production and expanded his business considerably. He wants expand his business further.

He would like to receive $1,200. With this loan he will to acquire 10 sheep and feed for them. He will repay the loan within 16 months. He hopes eventually to expand his business and further improve the living condition of his family.

loans.use: To buy 10 sheep and feed for them

loans.name: Rasheedan

texts.en: I am Rasheedan B.. I am married and a mother of six: three girls and three boys. My husband supplies various grocery items such as pulses, spices, detergents, etc. to different shops in the city. Earlier, my husband was very sick and could not work. Therefore, at that time, I started working as a sweeper in various posh houses for meager incomes. With such a small income, I had to take my husband to the doctor and put food on table for my children. I have been through very crucial economic crises. I thank God that my husband has recovered and our business is flourishing. Please lend us $300 to expand our business further. We plan to buy a stock of various grocery items such as spices and pulses. My husband is confident he can offer a secure future to his family.

loans.use: Buy a stock of grocery items

loans.name: Benta

texts.en: Benta is a 59-year-old mother of 8 living children. She lives with her husband in Nyamasaria Kisumu, Kenya. She is a poultry farmer, a venture she initiated in 2006. She keeps broilers, which grows fast (6 weeks) and are in high demand. She started her business with 100 chicks and now has 450. She sells mature broilers to hotels in town at US $4 a piece. She plans to expand the capacity of her poultry business by building an additional structure that can accommodate more chicks, buy chicken feed, and also employ 1 person to help her run the business. She has applied for US $800.

loans.use: Expand poultry business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate her stall and purchase an assorted stock of clothes

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en: Pamela is a 43-year-old widow. She lives with her three children (2 in school) in Nyamasaria Kisumu Kenya. She lost her husband due to HIV-related illness. Pamela, who is living positively, is a symbol of hope to many. With support from KMET, Pamela was able to acquire a popcorn fryer. She uses this to make popcorn, which she sells to the community, schools and also during events. Due to high demand, especially in schools, she plans to purchase another fryer with US $700 she has applied for.

loans.use: Buy a popcorn fryer.

loans.name: Lubomir

texts.en: Lubomir D. is married and lives with his wife in a house in the village of Rogozeno, near Vratza. For two years he has bred three cows. His wife helps him with the cows and takes care of their two children. Lubomir D. wants to buy one more cow and some feed and is applying for a $775 loan.

loans.use: To buy one more cow and some animal feed

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en: Sophie is a 49-year-old married mother of 8 children (2 still in school). She is very well-known within her community for her compassionate work, and also as a politician.  She is the women’s representative for Orange Democratic Movement in Siaya District, where her principal role is to speak to women, to raise awareness, and to encourage their involvement in the political process. Her main business and source of income, however, is her dairy cattle, which she has managed for the past two years.  She is able to sell no less than 21 litres of milk a day. She plans to use the funds from her next loan of US $1000 to purchase hybrid dairy cattle, construct  an additional shed, buy dairy cattle feeds, and also save the remaining to use in case of any emergency situations.

loans.use: Purchase hybrid dairy cattle

loans.name: Dafina

texts.en: Dafina V. lives with her boyfriend and has three children. Dafina breeds about 100 birds, mainly ducks and geese. Some of them have been bred for meat and some of them for eggs. Her boyfriend works as a builder. Dafina wants to make some repairs of the hen house and needs $775.

loans.use: To make some repairs to the hen house

loans.name: Tzetzka

texts.en: Tzetzka K. is registered as a private agricultural producer and breeds eight cows. She is married, and her husband works as a molder. They live in a house in the village of Medkovetz. Their two kids are grown and live separately.  Tzetzka K. needs to buy one more cow and is applying for a $775 loan.

loans.use: To buy one more cow

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is a 40-year-old mother of 6 children (2 in school). She lives with her husband at sagam village, Siaya District Kenya. She runs cereals and dairy farming businesses, initiated in 2002 and 2004 respectively. She normally buys dry maize in bulk during harvesting season, when prices are low, and sells in future when the price is high, thus making high profits. She supplements this with dairy farming where she is able to sell 20 litres a day. She applied for US $800 with which she plans to invest part of the loan to the purchase of cereals like beans and rice, and also buy local dairy breeds that can boost her daily milk production.

loans.use: Invest part of the loan in cereal business, and purchase local dairy breeds

loans.name: Georgi

texts.en: Georgi Z. has run his agricultural business since 2005. He breeds three cows in his cow shed and grows plums and raspberries on his 300 decares of land. His wife works in the municipality of Vratza. Georgi needs this $775 loan to buy seedlings.

loans.use: To buy seedlings

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience O., 42 years old, is from Edo State, married with 6 children. She sells tailoring materials. She has been a LAPO member for four years. She has been in business since 2003. She has repaid her first loan and she is requesting a loan of $800 to enable her to buy more tailoring materials for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials for sales

loans.name: Naiden

texts.en: Naiden K. lives with his wife and their three kids in the village of Rogozeno near Vratza. Until the last year, Naiden worked as a builder in the capital city, but now he has decided to start a farming business. Naiden has money for one cow and is applying for a loan to buy another. Naiden’s wife is unemployed and takes care of the kids. The loan amount is $775.

loans.use: To buy another cow

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is a 66-year-old widow who has also lost five of her children due to HIV-related illness. She is a hard-working mother, and well known in the community as a farmer. God has blessed her with a fertile piece of land where she grows staple crops mostly used in her community. She harvested bags of maize last season, which she hopes to sell when prices improve. She has another income: cattle rearing. She buys and sells cattle at a profit. The business has not done well, due to limited funds and competition from men who have overwhelmed this venture. She plans to purchase more cattle for sale and also rent additional land where she can grow more crops with US $700 she has applied for.

loans.use: Buy more cattle for sale and invest part of it in crop farming.

loans.name: Nikolinka

texts.en: Together with her husband, Nikolinka G. keeps 16 sheep and a cow. They also keep about 130-140 sheep belonging to their fellow villagers. Nikolinka and her husband live in a house with their three kids. The loan they apply for will be used to buy 10 more sheep.

loans.use: To buy 10 more sheep

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.en:
J. Dilafruz is the mother of two children. She lives with her parents as she is divorced. Her parents are pensioners and she supports all of them by her activity; trade of fabrics. She tries to make sure that her children do not need anything nor feel the shortage of a father's love. Her parents take care of her children when she is at her work and try to help their daughter as they can.

Her business loacted in J.Rasulov Clothing Market district of Khujand,Tadjikistan. She has been engaged in business for over 5 years and she has good experience as a skillful seller. Her turnover is fast and she has many regular clients. Currently she saves money for her boy's circumcision party (musulman tradition) in February.

From Kiva she is requesting extra capital for increasing the volume of her fabrics and making a good profit.

loans.use: Business expansion.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is a 32-year-old widow.  She lives in Sagam, Siaya Kenya. She used the funds from her first two loans to invest in this small corner shop (pictured) adjacent to her home, where she sells the daily necessities like bread, flour, cooking oil and soap and fresh milk.  She has since increased her daily income by 90% and managed to save a bit of her profits.  She plans to move her business into a larger space and a more lucrative location with US $600 she has applied for. She will use this money to pay rent for a larger shop, to increase her stock and to obtain supplies that are in high demand within her community.

loans.use: Increase stock in her retail shop and pay rent for a larger space.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en: Oscar is a 31-year-old trained clinical officer. He is married, and lives with his wife and 1 child in Chuka Kenya. Oscar, who qualified for clinical work in the year in 2000, worked with Consolata Cottage Clinic, in Chuka, three and half years. On the first of September 2005 he opened his own clinic, Chuka Medical clinic. His clinic is located in the middle of town and offers a range of health services including general curative, family planning, maternal and child health services and also has pharmacy, and a laboratory. The clients appreciate the quality of services provided at his facility. Oscar, who has received one previous loan from KMET, requires US $1200 to further expand his clinic.

loans.use: Clinic expansion

loans.name: Enakiz

texts.en: H. Enakiz is an experienced business woman. She has been in trade for 8 years. She has 5 children who help in her business. Her business is located in J. Rasulov clothing market, Khujand,Tajikistan. Every day her two sons help her to bring her goods from their home in a taxi to her trading place. In the evening, they help to gather goods. Enaki's dream is to purchase a car for her son's birthday and she is saving money for it. From Kiva, she wants to receive a loan to renovate her assortment and purchase modern warm clothes and boots.

loans.use: Purchasing  40 warm blouses, 50 suits and 60 pairs of shoes.

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en: U. Nodira is 36 years old, married and has 2 children. Her husband is unemployed, but he has his own microbus and transports people. Nodira has been dealing in children's clothes and boots for about 7 years. It is the single source of income for their family. In 2004, she became a client of Microinvest and she says that  it helped her to expand her business and receive a stable profit. By developing her business she was able to buy one milk cow and her daughter sells milk in their village. This summer, Nodira started to reconstruct her house. (The roof was very damaged by rains and snows, and the walls of the home were damaged.) She planned to finished the repairs by winter, but  she could not because lack of money. The weather is becoming cold now and she wishes that Kiva will help her with extra capital in the amount of $1175.

loans.use: For home reconstruction.

loans.name: Ishrat

texts.en: "I am Ishrat B. from a small town, Arifwala, Pakistan. I am a mother of two children, both of whom are too young to attend school at the present. When they are of the school-going age I plan to enroll them in a good school, which is relatively expensive.  I have been stitching clothes on order for last seven years, whereas my husband has a small store where he sells candies, spices and snacks. He needs to buy a few additional items for his store for which we request a loan of $175. My husband is a hardworking guy and a confident  father to offer wellbeing to the light of our eyes, our kids."

loans.use: Buy items for the store

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: "My name is Shamim A.. I am married and I live with my family in a small city, Arifwala, Pakistan.  I am a mother of four, three boys and one girl. Two of my elder children attend kindergarten whereas, the other two are not of school-going age yet. I mostly do my household chores but whenever I get time I embroider clothes for my friends and family. My husband supplies everyday use items such as pulses, soaps and snacks to various shops of the city. We need to expand our business and invest $275. We hope that this loan will be very useful for us to improve our business and thus our economic condition."

loans.use: Buy items such as pulses, snacks, toiletries in bulk

loans.name: Sharafniso

texts.en: Sharafniso is one of the active clients of Microinvest. She has high education as a teacher of  physicist and mathematics and has experience working at a school for over 10 years. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a worker in a factory, but his salary and her teacher's salary were not enough for the family needs and she decided to sell children's clothes at the market after her teaching work. Gradually she increased her working capital and teaching school was not essential and she devoted herself to her business completely. Today she skillfully sells her goods and her experience working at school helps her in personal contact with her clients. She services them with great attention and they become her constant clients. Currently she wants to get a loan for increasing her volume of goods, as she needs money for pay of her son's education.

loans.use: Increasing the volume of goods.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
My name is Nasreen B.. I want to have a loan for my husband who is a rickshaw driver.  He will use this loan to pay all the remaining installments of his rickshaw . This way he will no more have to pay heavy interest rate to the moneylender, if he manages to pay him upfront.
 I am a textile designer and I make designs on ladies shirts with sequins and other ornaments. Moreover, I am a mother of seven, five of whom attend a local school whereas the other two will be enrolled in school in a near future.Our economic conditions are not very good and we need to earn a better living for ourself.

loans.use: Pay for the installments of the rickshaw

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
I request a loan of $175 for my husband’s grocery store. He is a hardworking and a successful entrepreneur. He sells all the daily use items in his store. Last year, we took a loan for this business and increased the range of items in our store. The sale of our store increased significantly and generated decent profits for us. With the current loan he plans to stock various items adequately for his store.
I am a textile designer and I embroider clothes for my neighboring clients. Moreover, I am a mother of five, three boys and two girls. At present, only two of them attend school whereas the others are very small and do not attend school.

loans.use: Buy  various items for the store

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: My husband runs a knitwear business. He buys and sells various woolen items.Winter has just started and there is a high demand for woolen clothes.My husband feels that his business can do very well if he promptly responds to a high demand of these items. Therefore, a loan of $275 can do really well for us. With this money he plans to buy socks, vests, sweaters etc in a suitable quantity. I try to share  financial burden with my husband by sewing clothes for my neighborhood clientele. We both work very hard to support our four children. Your loan can help us to better feed and clothe ourselves.

loans.use: Buy a suitable quantity of knitwear

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am a mother of seven, four girls and three boys. My husband has a livestock business; he buys and sells cows. He is in this business for past many years. He works very hard to provide for us. If he is able to get a loan of $200 from you, he hopes to expand his business and add another cow. There is no one else here who could give us a loan, so please help us.

loans.use: Buy a cow for the business

loans.name: Gie Mayor Group

texts.fr:
Our objective is to buy staples in the cities of Dakar, Ziguinchor or Banjul and retail them locally. This will enable us to supply the local and surrounding populations and offer them easy access to essential goods without the major difficulties we always encounter. Our village is isolated and we are a long way from the main communication routes. This means, therefore, that our business will be extremely helpful to the eco-village population. Items will vary greatly in selection and according to demand. Some of us will sell foodstuffs, and others either cooking utensils and household goods, or clothing.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Notre objectif est de faire en sorte que nous puissions mettre sur place des produits de première nécessité que nous allions acheter dans les grandes villes (Dakar, Ziguinchor ou Banjul) et de les revendre au détail. Cette activité nous permettra de ravitailler les populations locales et environnantes d’avoir accès facilement aux produits de première nécessité sans les grosses contraintes que l’on rencontre tout le temps. En effet, notre village est isolé et nous sommes loin des voies de communication de grandes affluences. Ce qui fait donc que notre activité sera d’une grande utilité pour les populations de l’écovillage. Les articles seront très variés et en fonction de la demande. Parmi nous, il y aura ceux qui vont vendre des denrées alimentaires, d’autres des ustensiles de cuisine et de ménage et celles qui vendront des habits.

loans.use: To buy essential goods and foodstuffs, kitchen utensils, household goods and children’s clothing.

loans.name: Paula Matilde

texts.en:
Paula and her husband certainly have their hands full with six children, ranging from fourteen years to two months old.  Paula’s husband works as a gardener in areas around their community, while she balances the responsibility of Mom and entrepreneur at home.

Paula has started a small shop in her home, where she sells fashion accessories and undergarments.  Her products incluD. semi-precious jewels, hair ties, barrettes, decorative scarves, and other things as well.  Her inventory is small, and she plans on using her loan to maintain an assorted collection of these trinkets and fashionable accessories.  Paula hopes that her business will grow as quickly as her children, particularly her four boys, and that she will be able to generate income for her family while spending time at home.

loans.use: To Purchase Jewelry and Fashion Accessories

loans.name: Milciades

texts.es:
Mr. Milciades B. works in the fabrication of women’s intimate apparel along with his wife. They have been working in this field for more than 14 years.

They began with a family sewing machine, but currently they have three industrial sewing machines. They make more than two hundred items per week which they distribute in the capital. They are suppliers for different stores in various cities, and their business is going very well.

Milciades wants a loan in order to purchase raw materials like fabric, thread, bra straps, etc. in order to continue producing in large quantities since demand is increasing positively.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Milciades B. trabaja en la fabricación de ropas interiores para dama con su esposa hace ya más de 14 años.

Ellos comenzaron con una máquina de coser familiar, actualmente tienen tres máquinas de coser industriales y fabrican más de doscientas prendas por semana que distribuyen en la capital. Ellos son proveedores de diferentes tiendas en varias ciudades, y les va muy bien con el negocio.

El señor Milciades desea el préstamo para poder adquirir materia prima como telas, hilos, breteles, etc. para seguir produciendo en grandes cantidades ya que la demanda crece positivamente.

loans.use: Purchase raw material like fabric, thread, bra straps, etc.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes and her partner have three children together - two girls, fifteen and ten, and a boy, eight.  She bakes empanadas and prepares freshly squeezed juice for sale in her community.  Before school each morning, Mercedes’ children help her prepare the goods for sale that day.

Mercedes walks through the neighborhood, carting her empanadas and fresh juice.  Her customers vary daily, but the workingmen in the neighborhood regularly enjoy the freshly baked snacks and juice.  Mercedes plans on buying more fruit and other baking ingredients with her loan.  She explains that, with some good fortune, her business has plenty of growth potential.  Someday, Mercedes dreams of opening a buffet style luncheonette, where she can serve twenty to twenty five customers.

loans.use: Purchase of Baking Ingredients and Fruits for Empanada and Juice Sales

loans.name: Ramona Antonia

texts.en:
Ramona is in her early forties, and she and her husband have two boys aged twenty one and twenty years old.  Her elder son has finished secondary school and his brother should finish quite soon.  Ramona sells an assortment of clothing, presently catering to men.

Customers visit Ramona in her home, where they can find t-shirts, jeans, khaki pants, and tennis and dress shoes.  With her loan, Ramona plans on purchasing a selection of women’s clothing to dovetail with her men’s clothing offerings.  Ramona explains that she would like to have the financial flexibility to help her sons attend the local university.  In fact, Ramona hopes that she will have the opportunity to continue her education as well.

loans.use: Purchase of Men's and Women's clothing for sale

loans.name: Sujeidy

texts.en:
Sujeidy is twenty seven years old, and she and her partner have three children.  The youngest, one year old, does not wander too far from mom, while Sujeidy’s elder children, seven and four, attend school.  

Sujeidy is very humble, and quickly points out that her business is quite new, having only started in the last few weeks.  Currently, she sells men's and women’s clothing; mostly shoes and sneakers, along with a variety of bedtime wear.  With her loan, Sujeidy plans on focusing on women’s sleepwear and adding more shoes and sneakers to her selection.  Even though she is “just getting started,” Sujeidy explains that her enterprise will help her maintain a comfortable lifestyle for her family.  She hopes that her business will someday grow into a fully stocked clothing shop.

loans.use: Purchase of Women's Sleepwear and Men's and Women's shoes for sale

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis Gomez is a mechanic in Aregua, Paraguay. He has his own shop where he specializes in automotive electrical problems and also sells and installs car stereo equipment. He is married with a daughter of seven, who attends the local primary school. He and his wife, Maria Amelia, have been married for twelve years. Maria Amelia also works as a notary in the capital city, Asuncion.

Luis has worked in this field for more than 15 years. In 1993 he was forced to go to Argentina for work. It is there that he studied and gained experience working as an automotive electrician. He lived in Argentina for two years and then returned to his native Paraguay. Upon return he opened his store and has been working solo for the past thirteen years. Despite so many years of experience Luis is continuing to better his automotive skills. Today he is taking specific classes on fuel injection in hopes to better his knowledge and expand his shop.

He has asked for a loan to buy a car which he plans to renovate and sell as wel as some parts to complete this work. Luis is good humored and hard working. He is eager to undertake this new project and thankful for the financing opportunity provided by the Fundacion and Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a car and parts

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Elmina is a fishing town near Cape Coast, Ghana. The coast here is packed with fishermen and their fishing boats. Thus, the main economic activity in Elmina is fishing. The festival of ‘Baka Tue’ is coming soon and Adwoa G. is hoping to prepare by adding stock to her store with her loan. ‘Baka Tue’ is the day when the fishing ban is lifted. The community fishing ban lasts for several weeks in order for the fish in the area to populate.

Adwoa is expecting lots of business in the next couple of months from not only the festival, but also from the Christmas season where families will be gathering and cooking rice of all varieties. Adwoa will be using her loan to purchase rice, canned tomatoes, beans and other foods for the ‘Baka Tue’ and Christmas season for her shop inside the Elmina market.

Adwoa is a member of the Nyame Beba Group of Elmina. The group lending system allows several people to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

However, Adwoa is very hopeful about the profits that she will be making in the next couple of months. She will use her profits to further expand her shop and to pay the education fees of her 5 children. Her youngest child is almost graduating primary school and oldest is working hard in senior high school.

loans.use: Buy more rice, canned products (tomatoes, fish), oil to sell to people as the local festival, 'Baka Tue,' which is just about to begin, and store some for Christmas sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To replace his cab engine that is beyond repair

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is a member of the lending group, Nyame Beba of Elmina. These group members guarantee loans through a group repayment pledge. Peer support provides the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The five members of this group have known each other for many years and provide a lot of support for each other as they all work inside the Elmina market.

Francisca owns a small general store. She sells a variety of goods used in Ghanaian dishes. Francisca has been purchasing much of her stock on credit, paying her supplier back after she has sold the products. This allows Francisca to purchase a lot of goods with the little capital she has; however, buying stock this way generates very little profit, as most of the profit goes to her distributor. With her loan, she hopes to buy tomatoes, onions, oil, and her other stock in bulk, so she can make more profit.

Francisca is currently supporting her four children through school. Two of her children are in middle school and two are in elementary school.

loans.use: Increase her capital so that she can stop buying on credit and get more profit to sustain her business.

loans.name: Fredy Melchor

texts.es:
Fredy is a hard-working father who puts forth a lot of persistence and effort every day to offer well-being to his wife and kids. This immense love that he has in his heart motivates him in his daily work as a livestock farmer. He leaves his humble house very early to go to the fields to graze his animals so they can get their daily food from mother nature. He has a small stable in his home town, and this worthy trade is a family line of work. His father taught him how to raise animals efficiently, and this activity has been the main source of economic support for his family. He has now done intense livestock work for twelve years, and he hopes to continue to support his family with this work. More than anything, he hopes to cover the cost to educate his two smallest children to raise his family's quality of living. He is requesting your help through a loan to invest in the purchase of more fodder and to improve the conditions of his stable. Fredy is waiting patiently for your response and help so he can begin the plans he has decided on.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Fredy, es un padre de familia trabajador que pone cada día mucho empeño y esfuerzo para otorgarle bienestar a su esposa e hijos, este inmenso amor que cobija dentro de su corazón lo motiva en su diario desempeño ganadero. Abandona desde muy temprano su humilde morada para dirigirse al campo a pastar a sus animalitos a fin de que estos puedan conseguir su alimento diario de la madre naturaleza, tiene un pequeño establo en su tierra natal y este digno oficio es de formación familiar, su padre le enseñó eficientemente como criar a los animales y ahora esta actividad se ha constituido en el sostén económico principal de su familia.Ya han transcurrido doce años de intensa labor ganadera y Fredy desea continuar con el sostenimiento de su hogar con su desempeño, sobre todo para cubrir los gastos educativos de sus dos hijos más pequeños y para elevar el nivel de vida familiar; solicita tu ayuda a través de un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de forraje y mejorar las instalaciones de su establo.Freddy muy paciente aguardará tu respuesta y ayuda a fin de poner en marcha los planes que se ha propuesto

loans.use: Purchase of fodder (food for his cows and bulls) and improvements to the stable that shelters them.

loans.name: Martina

texts.es:
Martina R. is 53 years old, and has been married to Pablo Canete for more than 30 years. They have three adult children. Don Pablo is a shoemaker and he also helps his wife with her business. Martina has a small general store where she sells all kinds of basic goods like sugar, flour, beans, rice and other household items like thread, scissors, tape, buttons, etc. Martina began her business in a little shack and today she has a much larger store. She has been working with loans from the Paraguaya foundation since 2003 and is an excellent client. She is requesting a lona to purchase additional merchandise, particularly fruit, sugar, sodas, vegetables, canned goods and meats given that demand increases considerably at the end of the year.

Translated by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

La señora Martina R. tiene 53 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Pablo Cañete desde hace mas de 30 años, tienen tres hijos, todos mayores de edad.

Don Pablo es zapatero y a la vez ayuda a su esposa a llevar adelante su negocio. Martina tiene una despensa donde comercializa todo tipo de artículos de primera necesidad como ser azúcar, harina, fideos, arroz y además artículos varios de mercería: hilos, tijeras, cintas, botones, etc.

La señora Martina se inició con una pequeña casillita y hoy día ya cuenta con una mayor infraestructura, trabaja con créditos de la Fundación Paraguaya desde el 2003 y es una clienta excelente.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías especialmente frutas, azúcar, gaseosas, verduras, productos enlatados y carne pues en esta época de fin de año la demanda de estas mercaderías aumenta considerablemente.

loans.use: To purchase fruit, sugar, sodas, vegetables, canned goods and meat.

loans.name: Hortencia Group

texts.es:
The clients of the Hortencia group come from the village Tzucubal Ixtahuacan, which is quite far from the urban center and completely rural. Because of this, many of the women are quite timid at first, but after some time and funny stories, the ladies reflect their real personalities, those of self confident and very determined women.

Many of our clients in the communal bank Hortencia come from a very humble past. They have worked as weavers on a tiny scale, in the fields harvesting corn, fishing or washing clothes. However, when Friendship Bridge gave them the opportunity for a loan, they decided to change their future.

The majority of these clients are asking for a loan of approximately $300 US dollars. This reflects that these women are having business success. The success of their businesses can also be seen as a product of their constant work. The loan that this group is requesting will be their tenth from our institution.

The women will primarily use their loans to buy raw material in order to make typical dresses and in order to purchase and sell them. Although the credit that the majority of the women will receive will be invested in fabric and thereby could cause a saturation of the market, these clients are confident in the success of their business because Nahualá weaving is in great demand due to its quality and beauty.

Doña Lucia Quiché would love for her business to expand so that she could buy a car and not have to carry her merchandise to market every day. Manuela T., the treasurer of the communal bank, says that she wants her business to grow so that she can ensure the education of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Las clientas del grupo Hortencia vienen de la Aldea Tzucubal Ixtahuacan, la cual esta muy retirada del área urbana y es rural en esencia. Debido a eso, muchas de las clientas reflejan una actitud tímida al comienzo, pero luego de unas cuentas bromas ellas reflejan su verdadera personalidad, una de confianza en si mismas y muy determinante.

Muchas de nuestras clientas dentro del banco comunal Hortencia tuvieron un pasado muy humilde. Ellas han trabajado como tejedoras a pequeña escala, en el campo cosechando mazorcas en las milpas, pescando o lavando ropa. Sin embargo, cuando Friendship Bridge les dio la oportunidad de un préstamo ellas decidieron cambiar su futuro.

La mayoría de las clientas están solicitando un crédito de un monto alto de aproximadamente de US$300. Eso refleja que las clientas están teniendo negocios exitosos. El éxito de sus negocios también se puede ver como un producto a su constancia de trabajo. Este préstamo que van a solicitar va a ser su décimo préstamo con la institución.

Las señoras van a usar sus préstamos principalmente para la compra de materia prima para producir trajes típicos y para la compra y venta de ellos también. A pesar de que la inversión del crédito de la gran mayoría de señoras vaya a ser invertido en tejidos y pueda causar una sobre saturación de mercado, las clientas están confiadas en el éxito de sus negocios porque los tejidos de Nahualá tienen una demanda asegurada por la calidad y belleza de estos.

Doña Lucia Quiché le encantaría que su negocio se expandiera para que así ella pudiera comprar un carro y no tener que llevar su mercadería todos los días al mercado. Manuela T., la tesorera del banco comunal dice que ella quiere que su negocio crezca para que así ella pueda asegurarle la educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: To purchase raw material for making huipiles (traditional dresses).  To sell traditional clothing, dresses, and skirts.

payments.comment: Due to technical problems. The amounts repaid were not posted. Group Las Hortencias are doing great. They are paying back on time and have a little bit spare to save!

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Oscar is 50 years old, married to Delia. They have three children, one is married and the other two are university students, one is studying medicine and the other law.

Oscar worked for a few years in a jewelry shop where he learned how to make jewelry, then after acquiring enough experience he decided to become independent and he opened his own shop.

Today he makes and sells gold and silver jewelry, such as hoop earrings, rings, necklaces, bracelets, watches, etc. Oscar is asking for a loan to invest in the purchase of silver and gold to make his jewelry.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Oscar tiene 50 años, está casado y su esposa se llama Delia. Tienen tres hijos, uno de ellos ya esta casado y los otros dos son estudiantes universitarios, uno de ellos de la carrera de medicina y el otro de derecho (leyes).

Oscar trabajó varios años en un taller de joyería donde aprendió el oficio de joyero, luego de adquirir bastante experiencia decidió independizarse y abrio su propio taller.

Actualmente se dedica a la fabricación y venta de joyas de plata y oro, como aros, anillos, cadenas, brazaletes, relojes, dijes, etc. Oscar solicita el crédito para invertirlo en la compra de plata y oro para la fabricación de sus joyas.

.

loans.use: Purchase silver and gold to make jewelry.

loans.name: Jovino

texts.es:
Jovino is married, his spouse is named Cristina, they have 2 children and live in the Lugue. Jovine owns a metalsmithing business and a carpenter shop located in his home, for more than 5 years. His wife is a seamstress who makes school uniforms for the schools in their area. In this way she also contributes to the household income.

Jovino makes different types of furniture such as: tables, beds, chairs, dressers, etc. The loan he seeks is to purchase woods such as lapacho, petereby, ivyra pyta (all woods native to Paraguay) in bulk in order to be able to meet the orders that he has in his carpentry business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Jovino está casado, su esposa se llama Cristina, tienen 2 hijos, y viven en un barrio de la ciudad de Luque. Jovino posee una herrería y una carpintería ubicada en su domicilio hace más de 5 años. Su esposa se dedica a la confección de uniformes escolares para los colegios de la zona De esta manera ella también colabora con la economía familiar.

Jovino fabrica diferentes tipos de muebles, tales como: mesas, camas, sillas, roperos, etc. El préstamo que solicita es para la compra de maderas como ser: lapacho, petereby, ivyra pyta en mayor volumen y así poder cumplir con los pedidos que tiene para el trabajo en su carpintería.

loans.use: Purchase large quantities of different kinds of wood to make furniture

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Nearly every single day, one can find Catalina nestled behind a fragrant pile of herbs and flowers that she sells in the city center of Ayacucho, Peru. As one walks past Catalina and the other women lined up on either side of her on the busy city sidewalks, the relaxing scents of mint, thyme, and oregano waft into the air. Catalina brings these herbs and flowers fresh cut from the countryside every single morning and continues selling until the sun sets. Her clients consist of everyone from mothers preparing the daily meal to lovesick boyfriends buying flowers for their sweethearts. She even sells to traditional healers who use these herbs as medicines, as each one has a specific healing property, explains Catalina. For example, thyme is often used in teas to ease an upset stomach.

Flowers and herbs are not the only thing Catalina sells in the busy city. She and her husband own a small field just outside the city where they plant and raise several different types of potatoes which are then sold in Ayacucho and two times each year taken in large loads to the capital Lima where they are also sold in the markets. Additionally, Catalina buys large supplies of cereals such as corn and barley which she sometimes sells along with her flowers and herbs.

Catalina says it is only thanks to her village bank that she has been able to venture into so many markets. Thanks to the economic support she has received through loans, she was able to purchase her field and begin growing potatoes, as well as begin buying and selling cereals. With the money she has been saving in the bank, Catalina has many goals she wishes to accomplish. First and foremost, Catalina is intent on funding the education of all 9 of her children, three of whom are already studying in the local university. In addition to this, Catalina would also like to make improvements to her home. She is currently requesting a loan of US$ 500. The majority of this money will be spent on fertilizer for her potatoes, as they have just recently been planted and are beginning to grow. The rest of the money will be spent on the purchase of large supplies of cereals to be sold in the city.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for potatoes and cereals to sell in the city

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Ceviche, Peru’s national dish, consists of fresh fish, lime, and spices, and anyone who is planning to prepare this delicious and healthy meal can stop by Sonia’s stand in the fish market to buy all the necessary ingredients in one trip. Located just inside the door of the local fish market in Ayacucho, Perú, Sonia provides the lime, onions, tomatoes, spices, lettuce, chilies, and everything else used to prepare both ceviche and fried fish, another Peruvian favorite. Her clients consist of everyone from mothers shopping for the day’s meal to large seafood restaurants. Every single day of the week, one can find Sonia at her stand, with her busiest days being Saturday and Sunday when the largest shipments of fish arrive from the coastal capital of Lima.

Although she loves ceviche and loves her job, Sonia’s aspirations lie in a different field. One day, she says she would love to open a store specializing in spices. There is much more demand and the prices are higher in this market, she explains. The larger profit potential would be especially welcome in Sonia’s household these days as she has two little daughters ages 3 and 4. Everything she does is for her daughters and she works and saves diligently to be able to provide a better life for the two of them.

Sonia’s participation in her village bank is what has helped her grow her business and earn capital for the past 4 years, as she works towards the many goals she has set for herself and her business. She says she loves to be involved because her village bank has taught her how to save her money in the bank where it safely accumulates interest. There she has also learned the value of punctuality and responsibility. Sonia is currently requesting a loan of US$ 425. This money she will invest in a car which will greatly help her in the purchase and shipment of the products she sells daily.

loans.use: To invest in a car

loans.name: Vicente

texts.es:
"My wife and I have a notions and paper supply store, which has been a lot of work and sacrifice to make it successful but now we need a little money to be able to invest in the purchase of merchandise and thereby increase our earnings." I am asking for US$1000 to invest in my business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

“Mi esposa y yo tenemos un negocio de Mercería y Papelería, nos ha costado mucho trabajo y sacrificio levantarlo pero ahora necesitamos un poco de dinero para poder invertir en la compra de más mercancía y así poder aumentar nuestras ganancias”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Lidia Maruja

texts.en:
Lidia owns and runs the friendly grocery store at which everyone stops in her small neighborhood just outside the city center of Ayacucho, Peru. She opened her doors just one year ago, and already has a steady flow of regular customers who pass through her doors shopping for their daily needs. Just as any clever business woman does, Lidia is constantly looking for opportunities to give her the advantage and attract new customers. For this reason, she has just recently had the idea to purchase tables and set up a small area where people can come over after work and have a beer or soda with their friends.

Before opening her store, Lidia was working as a waitress in her aunt’s seafood restaurant. Although she enjoyed it, Lidia’s real dream was to work for herself, independently. Three years ago, Lidia joined FINCA to take out loans and invest in her aunt’s business. Meanwhile, she was slowly saving her earnings in the bank. Eventually she had enough money saved up to strike out on her own and open her grocery store.

This enterprising dream that Lidia has realized would not have been possible without the help she receives from her village bank. There she has learned how to save her money formally in the bank, where it is safe and accumulates interest, and the loans she has received have been of an immense help. She is now requesting a loan of US$ 350. With this money, she will buy new tables to set up a nice space to realize her newest idea of a small bar.

loans.use: Buy new tables for her store

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Together, Feliciana and her husband have owned and operated a thriving business in carpentry and wood sales for more than 15 years. While her husband hand crafts beautiful pieces of furniture, Feliciana takes care of the logistical side of the business taking out loans and managing all financial aspects. Chairs, tables, armoires, and many other exquisite pieces of work are produced within the walls of their workshop which is set up next door to their small home. Once each week, a large bus is rented to take them just outside the city limits of Ayacucho, Peru, where they purchase huge supplies of wood to bring home and craft. As well, they also take a portion of the wood supply to a Sunday market, where it is sold to other carpenters in the area. They also bring their hand-crafted furniture and sell it at the market.

Feliciana has accomplished a great deal in the past 15 years, much of which she attributes to the great help provided her through her village bank. After her first three years of taking out loans and saving money, she and her husband were able to buy a car. Three years after that, they bought a large truck for wood shipments. Today, they continue to save with the goal of funding the university education of her 2 sons. As well, Feliciana would very much like to open a small grocery store from their home, and they are currently in the process of adding a second floor to their house. These are ambitious goals that Feliciana has set for herself, however, she has proven several times over that when she sets a goal, she accomplishes it.

Through her hard work, Feliciana has been able to provide amazing opportunities to her family, and because of this they all appreciate her participation in her village bank. Feliciana’s involvement has become a family affair. She describes how all of her children place great value on the bank because of the great economic help is has provided for all of them over the past 15 years. Feliciana is requesting a loan of $500. With this money, she and her husband will begin to stock up large supplies of wood in preparation for December and January, their busiest months of the year.

loans.use: Stock up on large supplies of wood

loans.name: Sandra Alina

texts.en:
Sandra Alina is a talented and friendly businesswoman involved in three different ventures in order to support her family. The majority of her time is dedicated to the sale of beauty products. Much like Avon or Mary Kay, Sandra sells “Esika” beauty products. She is an obvious natural as she loves to chat and socialize with her customers who come to her for every beauty product need from shampoos to perfumes to cosmetics. She loves her work, she explains, because she has turned something she loves to do into a moneymaking business. In addition to “Esika,” Sandra and her husband have created a successful business selling ornamental fish. Their home is filled with four small aquariums and one giant aquarium that house beautiful fish of all varieties. They are shipped from Lima and her husband attends to the customers who stop by to pick out their new pet.

Although she loves the work she is currently involved in, Sandra is very excited about a new venture. She has recently finished taking classes at a local university where she learned how to make stuffed animals and she now has orders rolling in to create fun toys for children. It takes her about 2 days to create one extremely large stuffed animal which she is able to sell for about 40 Nuevo Soles (US$ 13.50). The majority of the orders she has filled so far have come from teachers wanting to decorate their classrooms, which serves as a great way for Sandra to advertise her new product. Sandra really feels fulfilled doing this business because she is able to use her creativity and takes much pride in her final product. Her goal is to eventually turn her newfound talent in making stuffed animals into a fulltime business.

Sandra has been involved in her village bank for nearly 10 years, and she loves it. Thanks to the loans she receives, she is able to pursue her passions with economic security, and this is very valuable. She is currently working hard to save her money to be able to send her son on a class field trip to Cusco. It is a tradition here in Ayacucho that the class graduating into high school takes a special trip. Sandra’s son won’t be graduating for another 2 years, but the trip is so expensive that the families are already saving money and making payments. With the $350 loan Sandra is requesting, she will invest in all three of her business ventures, but the majority will go towards her husband’s fish business and materials to create stuffed animals.

loans.use: To invest in fish business and buy materials to create stuffed animals

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es:
Blanca is a woman determined to search for the best things in life, and offer them to her dearly loved children. This eagerness means that she is always on the lookout for profitable new activities. Driven by the love of her family, she works hard traveling round to different town markets and selling clothes. She is accompanied and helped by her sister, who encouraged her to do this two years ago, when she moved to settle in her home town. She devoted herself to selling clothes, and now she is satisfied as her business selling girls’ clothes provides her with sufficient income to cover the cost of primary and secondary education for her four young children. And now Blanca has a new reason to be happy: twenty days ago she gave birth to her latest child, and is currently at home recovering her strength before returning to her work, accompanied by her new bundle of joy. Now she has even greater desires and intends to work even harder for her little ones.

Blanca is requesting your help in getting a loan to set up a small shop in her home, so that she can keep an eye on her baby and also look after the rest of her family. Your support means a great deal to Blanca; please offer her your help.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

Blanca es una mujer decidida a buscar lo mejor para ofrecérselos a sus queridos hijos y por este afán siempre está en búsqueda de nuevas y ventajosas ocupaciones, impulsada por el amor de su familia se esfuerza trabajando en la venta de prendas de vestir de manera ambulante en las ferias de cada centro poblado que encuentre y lo hace con la compañía y ayuda de su hermana; quien la animó hace dos años a que lo hiciera cuando se mudo para establecerse en su tierra natal. Se dedicaba a la venta de vestidos y hoy se siente satisfecha porque su negocio de venta de vestidos para niñas le otorga las ganancias suficientes para cubrir los gastos primarios y secundarios de sus cuatro pequeños hijos y ahora tiene una nueva alegría más debido a que hace veinte días alumbró al íltimo de sus retoños y se está en casa hasta que se reponga completamente para continuar con su labor en compañía de su nueva alegría. Ahora tiene muchos más deseos y espera trabajar aún más por sus pequeños.
