Recurre en tu ayuda con el objetivo de obtener un préstamo a fin de establecerse en una pequeña tienda que habilitará en las inmediaciones de su casa para estar al pendiente de su bebé y también al cuidado del resto de su familia.Recuerda tu apoyo será muy significativo e importante para Blanca, decídete a brindarle tu ayuda.

loans.use: To set up an area in her home as a shop, so that she can sell clothes while taking care of her baby.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
In the Santa Clara market in the middle of Ayacucho, Perú, Lilia sits on a stool behind a mountain of fresh vegetables and grains. For the past 10 years, Lilia, or “Liliana,” as her friends and neighbors know her, has been selling carrots, celery, tomatoes, onions, broccoli, cauliflower, and just about every other vegetable imaginable to her community in this small Andean city.

Before there were vegetables, there were cereals. These Lilia also sold and continues to sell in the market from her stand. The cereals consist of everything from wheat to barley, and they come from the country just outside the city limits. After several years of selling only cereals, it was clear to Lilia that she was not making enough profit to support a healthy lifestyle. Thus, she decided she needed to increase the variety of products she sold in order to supplement her income. This she did, and it is now to vegetables that she dedicates the majority of her time and energy. She happily reports that her decision was a great success, and she now serves a large number of regular customers counting on her for their daily supply of leafy greens and cereals. It is a very important business concept, explains Lilia. If one does not provide a variety of products, the customers will shop elsewhere.

This motivated 27 year-old has many goals and aspirations for her growing vegetable business. She says she is always looking for ways to improve, and she has her eye set on a permanent stand within the market. Currently, Lilia is an “ambulante,” which means she sells from a mobile stand and spends most of the day walking. A permanent stand would allow her greater consistency and the supply of a much greater quantity of products. This is an especially important time for Lilia to be expanding her business as she is newly pregnant with her first child. Thanks to her village bank, such expansion is a real possibility. For the past 3 years, Lilia has learned how to save her money and she says thanks to her bank, she has increased exponentially the amount of products she is able to move daily. Lilia is requesting a loan of $550. With this money, she will buy larger quantities of cereals and vegetables, especially carrots.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of cereals and vegetables, especially carrots

loans.name: Mauricia

texts.en:
This single mother of two teenagers owns and manages two different businesses. The venture to which she dedicates the majority of her time is a stand selling candies on a busy street in Ayacucho, Peru. She tends to this stand every single day of the week. As an “ambulante,” Mauricia has a stand on wheels, and when business is slow in one area, she has the capability to pick up and move to a more profitable section, taking advantage of greater flows of traffic. Mauricia explains that she loves her job because she is her own boss and it allows her the freedom to move about, taking advantage of the most visited and traffic-heavy areas of the city.

Although she enjoys selling candies, Mauricia’s second business is the one she is working to develop into a full-time job. This business consists of renting out the “moto-taxi” she saved so diligently to buy. A moto-taxi is a type of covered three-wheel motorcycle with a backseat, and they are the principal means of public transportation throughout this small Andean city. Every morning, the chauffeur to whom she has rented the taxi drives her to her stand and then he sets off earning money during the day. Mauricia charges 25 Soles per day to rent her taxi, or about US$ 8.50. This is an ideal way to make a living, explains Mauricia, and her dream is to save up enough money to buy a fleet of taxis that she would rent out daily.

A major factor allowing her to work diligently toward her dream business has been her involvement with her village bank. Having been the catalyst to her hard work and savings, Mauricia is very grateful to her bank. There, she has learned how to save her money and has received the economic support necessary to grow her business and accumulate capital. The reason she works so hard is to put food on the table for her children and facilitate their high school and college educations. Thanks to the loans she receives, this is a goal that is always met.

Mauricia is requesting a loan of US$ 425. This money will be put toward the repair of her moto-taxi because although it is profitable, it not necessarily a reliable type of automobile, requiring continual maintenance. She will buy new tires and cylinders.

loans.use: To buy new tires and cylinders for her moto-taxi

loans.name: Lili

texts.es:
Cabanillas is home to young, enthusiastic, 23-year-old Lili, who decided to leave her home town and go to the city of Juliaca in search of a better future. With a great deal of effort, Lili and her sister Teodora – who provided unwavering support – were able to set up a small stall selling clothes. Thanks to their perseverance, the variety of their merchandise, and above all the modest prices they offer, their business is providing a reasonable income.

It is Lili’s wish to have more capital to invest in a greater quantity and variety of merchandise, with the goal of generating more income in order to pay for her secondary education, which she is currently completing at a city approved high school. To implement her plans, Lili is requesting a loan, which, thanks to your kind contribution, will allow her to meet her objective.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

El distrito de Cabanillas es el pueblo natal de Lili, joven entusiasta de 23 años que decidió partir en busca de un mejor porvenir hacia la ciudad de Juliaca; actualmente con el apoyo incondicional de su hermana Teodora y con mucho esfuerzo han podido constituir un puestito de ventas de prendas de vestir, negocio que gracias a su perseverancia, variedad de mercadería y sobre todo a los preciosos módicos con las que los ofrecen están obteniendo satisfactorios y beneficiosos ingresos.

El deseo de Lili es contar con más capital para invertirlos en la compra de mayor cantidad y variedad de mercadería con el objetivo de incrementar sus ingresos económicos para cubrir satisfactoriamente los gastos de los estudios superiores que viene realizando en un reconocido instituto de su ciudad. Para concretar sus planes solicita un préstamo de dinero que gracias a tu gentil colaboración le permitirá cumplir con su objetivo.

loans.use: To buy a greater quantity and variety of clothing to sell in the local city market.

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
We find Roxana doing her daily work of making jackets and gloves; she learned the beautiful art thanks to her older sister Norma's teaching her, and since then, with much creativity and patience she makes her beautiful items of clothing in her small shop, beneath her watchful eyes and support of her dear mother and sister. After five years of craftsmanship she acquired two weaving machines, but it is still insufficient to meet the large number of orders that she receives daily.

This 27 year old young mother is asking for a loan in order to be able to purchase a large quantity and variety of raw material (wool) in order ot make her beautiful garments. The wish of this hard-working mother of a 10 month old baby is to be able to export her creations to neighboring countries, and above all, to increase her income in order to be able to remodel her humble home which she bought recently with the help of her husband José, who works as a messenger for the Banco del Trabajo. We support this enthusiastic mother who with talent and effort, wishes to improve her family's future.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Encontramos a Roxana realizando su trabajo cotidiano de confección de chompas y guantes; ella aprendió este bello arte gracias a la enseñanza de su hermana mayor Norma y desde entonces con mucho creatividad y paciencia confeccionan sus hermosas prendas de vestir en su pequeño taller bajo las atentas miradas y apoyo de su querida madre y hermana.Después de cinco años de haberse dedicado permanentemente a este oficio ha adquirido dos máquinas de tejer, pero aún es insuficiente para cumplir con la gran cantidad de pedidos que recibe diariamente.

La solicitud de esta joven madre de 27 años de edad servirá para que pueda adquirir mayor cantidad y variedad de materia prima (lana) para la confección de sus hermosas prendas. El deseo de esta laboriosa madre de un bebé de diez meses es porque desea exportar sus confecciones a los países vecinos y sobre todo para incrementar sus ingresos a fin de poder refaccionar su humilde casita que compró hace poco con ayuda de su esposo José, quien se desempeña como mensajero en el Banco del Trabajo.Apoyemos a esta madre entusiasta que con talento y esfuerzo desea salir adelante con su familia.

loans.use: Purchase a large quantity and variety of raw materials to make her clothing items

loans.name: Graciela

texts.en:
Graciela is truly an entrepreneur. Nearly twenty years ago when she married her husband, she assumed the administrative duties in his carpentry business while he took care of the manual labor. Graciela joined her village bank and began taking out loans and together, the happy couple built a thriving business. All the while she was administrating the carpentry business, Graciela describes how it was a dream of hers to open her own independent grocery store in order to further supplement the family’s income. Little by little, she saved her money and eventually accumulated enough capital in the bank to open a beautiful little grocery store out of her home.

Today, seven years after opening her grocery store, Graciela is the proud owner of her own thriving business. She has wisely acquired a photocopy machine as the students and teachers attending the nearby high school are always in need of copies. As time passes, Graciela continues looking for different products she can add to her store, giving her an advantage over her competition.

Graciela lists a number of goals and reasons to be saving her money at this point in time. First of all, her 17-year-old son is about to enter the local university and would like a computer for his studies. Graciela is very proud to be saving towards such a goal. A second reason she saves is to pay for medical treatments, as she has recently fallen quite ill. She suffers from severe kidney pains and a grave case of hemorrhoids. To this point, the treatments she has received have been unsuccessful, and she plans to travel to Lima, Perú, for better medical attention.

For these reasons, Graciela is very grateful to have been a part of her village bank for the past 15 years. Thanks to the value of saving she has been taught, Graciela has some savings in the bank to pay for things like medical emergencies and educational opportunities for her son. Apart from the economic help she receives, Graciela happily describes the lifelong friendships she has made that serve as a distraction from the difficulties of life. Graciela hopes to invest the $350 loan she is requesting in her husband’s business. He has recently been contracted for a large project building doors and needs the loan to get started.

loans.use: To invest in her husband's carpentry business

loans.name: Juana Elena

texts.en:
Elena has a steady job as an independent breakfast caterer for a construction company in Lima. Every morning she wakes up at 3 AM to prepare breakfast for 100 construction workers. After six long hours of preparing food she then delivers it to their building. After this, she begins preparations on the next morning’s meal. She has a very diverse menu which she changes every day; she says both she and the workers enjoy the variety! Elena has run this business for five years, and has one employee who helps her.

Elena has been a single mother her entire life. She has three children; her two older children, ages 22 and 20, are both independent and working, and her youngest, 18, lives with her and is studying at the university. She dreams that her kids can be professionals so they can have the things in life that she hasn’t been able to give them.

Elena loves her catering business, but her real dream is to open up a restaurant in her home so she doesn’t have to transport the food each day. With this loan of $150 she plans on buying the necessary ingredients for her breakfasts so she can ‘seguir adelante’, keep on moving forward, and continue to put away money in savings towards opening her own restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the breakfasts she prepares

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a young artist of 19. She studied art in high school, and now works in a studio from 6:00 to 11:00 pm constructing and painting "Manualidades en Trupan", crafts made on a special type of wood found in Peru, which vary from beautiful paintings and woodcarvings to colorful jewelry boxes. She can produce a painting for about nine Soles ($3) and sell it for 15 Soles ($5), and she can produce a jewelry box for six Soles ($2) and sell it for 10 Soles ($3.25).

Cecilia found out about her village bank from her mom, who is also with Finca. She has been with them for three months now, and will use this loan of $150 to buy materials such as wood and paint. She loves what she does and is looking forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: To buy wood, paint, and other materials needed for her paintings

loans.name: Rosa Elizabeth

texts.en:
Rosa is a single mother with a 6-year-old son. Her primary business is selling clothing from her home in Lima, and a year ago she started selling cosmetics as well to earn more money.

Rosa is very interested in fashion and enjoys selling the clothes and the cosmetics. She purchases the clothes in bulk from a wholesaler in Lima, and sells them from her home to friends and relatives who have come to count on her for their clothing needs. She can buy a pair of jeans for 30 Soles ($10) and sell them for 50 Soles ($17). As a single mother, she needed to increase her income, and a friend recommended she begin selling cosmetics for the company Esika, similar to Mary Kay or Avon. It was easy for her to jump right into this, because several of the regular customers from her clothing business were also interested in purchasing cosmetics from her.

Rosa lives in a house with 12 other people. She comes from a family of eight children, and lives with all of her siblings and their children. Unfortunately, one of her siblings recently passed away, and that has left a deep sadness in their home. She would love to be able to someday purchase her own house where she and her son can live. Her son is in school, and even at the young age of six has a dream of becoming an engineer!

Rosa’s dream for her business is to open a store where she can display and sell all her clothing, but it is very expensive to do this: the initial investment would be around 5000 Soles (about $1700). With this loan of $150 Rosa will buy 10 pairs of jeans to sell, and the profit from this will go towards her dream of opening her own store.

loans.use: To buy 10 pairs of jeans to sell

loans.name: Manuela Ysabel

texts.en:
Ysabel has the true spirit of an entrepreneur.  She is the mother of four and her husband paints houses for a living, and up until recently, Ysabel contributed a small income from selling cosmetics through a company called Esika, similar to Mary Kay or Avon.  Six months ago, a friend invited her to her village bank, and Ysabel went to a meeting just to meet new people.  While she was at the meeting she became inspired and thought ‘I could do this, I could start a business!’  She loves to cook and decided to turn this passion into a means of building capital.  She now prepares a different dessert each week, such as picarones (similar to a doughnut), mazamorra (made with corn and fruit), and arroz con leche, and sells them from a cart on the street.  She also cooks carne de res, a type of meat.  

Ysabel and her husband have four children, ages 18, 15, 11, and 2.  Her oldest is now studying cosmetology.  Isabel’s parents are getting older and now live with her family, so she has two additional people to care for.  She is still selling cosmetics, but is focusing on her new business.  The positive reaction she’s gotten about her food has empowered her, and she now has a dream to open her own restaurant.  Ysabel says that with each loan she will get closer to this dream, and when she gets there, she is going to name the restaurant after her youngest son, her inspiration.  With this loan of $150 Ysabel will purchase the necessary ingredients, such as corn, fruit, honey, milk, and rice to prepare her food.

loans.use: To purchase the necessary ingredients, such as corn, fruit, honey, milk, and rice to prepare her food.

loans.name: Manuela Ysabel

texts.en:
Ysabel, mother of four, has the true spirit of an entrepreneur. Her husband paints houses for a living, and up until recently, Ysabel contributed a small income from selling cosmetics through a company called Esika, similar to Mary Kay or Avon. Six months ago, a friend invited her to her village bank, and Ysabel went to a meeting just to meet new people. While she was at the meeting she became inspired and thought ‘I could do this, I could start a real business!’ She loves to cook and decided to turn this passion into a means of building capital. She now prepares a different dessert each week, such as picarones (similar to a doughnut), mazamorra (made with corn and fruit), and arroz con leche, and sells them from a cart on the street. She also cooks carne de res, a type of meat.

Ysabel and her husband have four children, ages 18, 15, 11, and 2. Her oldest is studying cosmetology. Isabel’s parents are getting older and now live with her family, so she has two additional people to care for. She is still selling cosmetics, but is focusing on her new business. The positive reaction she’s gotten about her food has empowered her, and she now has a dream to open her own restaurant. Ysabel says that with each loan she will get closer to this dream, and when she gets there, she is going to name the restaurant after her youngest son, her inspiration. With this loan of $150, Ysabel will purchase the necessary ingredients, such as corn, fruit, honey, milk, and rice to prepare the food she sells.

loans.use: To purchase the necessary ingredients, such as corn, fruit, honey, milk, and rice to prepare her food.

loans.name: Maria Angela

texts.en:
Maria is in the popular and high-demand business of taxis in Lima. She owns one taxi and one mototaxi (a motorcycle with a covered seated area attached to carry passengers) that she rents out daily. She rents to the same people each day, and charges 35 Soles ($12) for the taxi and 20 Soles ($7) for the mototaxi per day, seven days a week. Maria has been renting out the taxi for six years, and she purchased the mototaxi three years ago. She also sells soft drinks and snacks from a cart outside her home.

Maria and her husband have two children, ages 16 and 6. Her older son wants to go into Peru’s Air Force, and her younger son dreams of being a doctor and a pilot. Maria’s dream for her business is to purchase a combi, a small bus that is a common method of transportation in Lima. She could greatly increase her income with the addition of a combi, but it would be an expensive investment so she needs to wait with this awhile. With this loan of $175, she will buy parts for her taxis and make necessary repairs.

loans.use: To buy parts for her taxis and make necessary repairs

loans.name: Casilda

texts.en:
Casilda is a single mother of two. She is in the popular business of taxi rental, and owns a taxi and a mototaxi (a motorcycle with a covered seated area attached to carry passengers) that she rents out daily. She rents to the same people each day, and charges 30 Soles ($10) for the taxi and 25 Soles ($8.25) for the mototaxi. Casilda also buys clothes wholesale and sells them from her home. Christmas is the busiest time of year for this, especially for Christmas dresses for girls.

Casilda’s two sons, ages 24 and 23, both live with her. Her older son is working at a supermarket chain in Lima, and her younger son works for her with her taxi rental. She has been with her village bank for 10 years and says it has helped her a lot. Her dream for her business is to open her own shop to sell her clothes. She also has a goal of buying her own home. With this loan of $175 Casilda will fix the tires on her taxis and perform other necessary maintenance, and she will also purchase dresses to sell for Christmas.

loans.use: To fix the tires on her taxis and purchase dresses to sell for Christmas

loans.name: Rocio Del Pilar

texts.en:
Rocio has a successful business cooking and selling tamales in Lima. She has five carts and four employees who each run at cart at a different location. She’s found that business is better if you can sell in various locations versus being in a permanent stand. Rocio sells only on the weekends, and spends the very early morning hours of Saturday and Sunday preparing the tamales: it takes almost 5 hours to cook them, and they are best served hot, so she can’t prepare them ahead of time.

Rocio and her husband have three children, ages 12, 10, and 2. Her dream for her business is to keep expanding by adding more carts throughout the city. She has started to sell at fairs as they come through Lima, and has found this to be an excellent source of additional income, so she would like to sell at fairs more frequently. With this loan of $150, Rocio will buy corn and other ingredients (such as flour and meat) for her tamales, all the ingredients for which she buys from a local market.

loans.use: To buy corn and other ingredients for the tamales she makes and sells

loans.name: Emperatriz

texts.en:
Emperatriz is a true renaissance woman! She’s currently involved in four different businesses. Her primary business is selling food; she prepares anticuchos (shish kabobs), salchipapas (sausage with fries), hamburgers, and other foods and sells them, along with soft drinks, from a stand outside of her home. She sells the food from 7:00 to 11:00 am. As a second business, she buys toys wholesale and sells them as Christmas presents.

Emperatriz also sells cosmetics for a company called Esika, similar to Mary Kay or Avon, and this has lead her to her true passion- cosmetology. She is currently studying cosmetology three days a week, for five hours a day. She finishes in December and will be ready to practice, which she plans to do from her home, however she would love to study an additional six months to become trained in manicures and pedicures as well. Her dream is to open a beauty salon, but she also wants to continue with her other businesses—she realizes to do this she might need to hire some help!

Emperatriz has two children, ages 17 and 9. Her oldest just finished high school and is now preparing for college. With this loan of $125 Emperatriz will buy ingredients for her food stand, such as potatoes and meat, as well as toys to sell for Christmas.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her food stand

loans.name: Vicenta Hilda

texts.en:
Vicenta is in the business of taxis, a very popular and high-demand business in the massive city of Lima. She and her husband own two taxis that they rent out daily. They rent to the same people each day, and charge 40 Soles (about US$ 13) per taxi each day. The drivers are responsible for paying for the gas, but Vicenta is responsible for making all repairs, which are necessary quite often, as the taxis are driven 15 hours a day (from 7am to 10pm), 7 days a week.

Vicenta also cooks picarones, a very popular doughnut-type dessert, and sells them during the day outside of her home. She and her husband have two grown children, ages 30 and 28. With this loan of $175, Vicenta will repair some tires on the two taxis, and the rest will go towards fixing one of the motors- a very expensive undertaking at 3500 Soles (about US$ 1150), but a necessary investment.

loans.use: To purchase tires for her taxis and part toward fixing a motor on one

loans.name: Felicita Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea has a very successful catering business in Lima. People call her to cater birthdays, business lunches, and other special occasions. Up until two years ago, she also worked for a restaurant where she learned everything about the business, but had to quit that job because of painful arthritis in her leg. She has also had to reduce the amount of her loans due to the expensive treatment she is receiving for this problem.

Even though Andrea is facing tough medical challenges, her zest and determination for her business won’t let anything stop her. When she has a catering job, she prepares what she can ahead of time from her kitchen in her home, and then she transports everything to the catering location by taxi. She has a set of pans and appliances that she brings with her to prepare the rest of the food on location, and has four or five people to help her, depending on the size of the catering job. She prepares a lot of Italian and Chinese food, but the most common is the popular Peruvian ‘comida Criolla’. Christmas is a very busy time for her: she receives many requests for cooking Christmas day turkeys, and she can currently prepare six turkeys, for which she charges 60 Soles ($20) a piece. She would love to have the capability to prepare more!

Andrea has five children, ages 32, 31, 29, 27, and 25, all now independent and working in Lima. Andrea’s dream is to expand her kitchen to enable her to prepare more food at once. She would especially like more counter space and a larger oven. She is also in the process of designing business cards to hand out and has very creative ideas for her logo! When asked if the loans help her, her eyes light up and she gives a very enthusiastic ‘yes!’. She says they help her immensely, and she is very excited for this loan of $350 to be able to invest in her business cards, more pans, and a blender.

loans.use: To invest in business cards, more pans, and a blender.

loans.name: Juana Rina

texts.en:
Juana is a caring and insightful mother of four. Her three oldest children are 27, 26, and 24, and her youngest daughter is 9 years old. She has a business cooking food, such as stuffed potatoes and picarones (a doughnut type dessert), which she sells to friends and neighbors from her home on the weekends. She sells the stuffed potatoes for one Sol apiece, about 35 cents. She also occasionally prepares lunches for schools.

Juana’s husband is the driver of a combi (a small bus very common in Lima), and they live in their own home with three of their children- their oldest is married and lives with her in-laws. During the week Juana is busy taking care of their youngest daughter. She says this can be exhausting, getting her ready each morning and helping her study each afternoon, and making sure she gets to all of her activities. She loves her village bank for the adult community it brings her. She says the meetings are stimulating for her mind and she enjoys the challenge it brings to her life. With this loan of $425 Juana will buy potatoes, flour, oil, onions, meat, and some new plates with which to serve the food.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, flour, oil, onions, meat, and some new plates with which to serve the food

loans.name: Sina Uelese

texts.en: Sina is a 52-year-old lady who is married with five children. She is very glad to have joined SPBD’s loan program as it has helped her develop her farm which provides the income for her family. She has been in the program for a long time, and this is the largest available loan to members. This is her sixth loan, and it will be used to expand her farm and for home improvement. The farm is already quite big and helps her family meet financial commitments. She hopes to stay in the loan program for a long time.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and tools for her farm and make home improvements

loans.name: Keyttel Januaria

texts.es:
Mrs. Keyttel Januaria C. M. is 24 years old and is from the city of Bluefields. She is married to Mr. Carlos Bacon and the couple has one daughter who is 5 years old. This young entrepreneur has one year of experience in silver jewelry sales. Her clients for the most part are women between 18 and 60 years old and on occasion men between 21 and 31 make purchases because she offers specialized service and delivery. Mrs. C. needs to buy 7 units of bracelets at $27.00 per unit and 5 sets of earrings and charms at $22.00 each set to be able to augment her inventory and in this way satisfy customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Keyttel Januaria C. M. tiene 24 años de edad, es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, esta casada con el Sr. Carlos Bacon ambos tienen 1 hija de 5 años de edad. Esta joven emprendedora tiene 1 año de experiencia en la venta de joyas de plata sus clientes en la mayoría son mujeres de 18 a 60 años y en ocasiones le compran hombres de 21 a 31 años que la prefieren porque ofrece un servicio especializado y a domicilio. La Sra. C. necesita comprar 7 unidades de pulseras a $27.00 dólares cada unidad, 5 juegos de aretes y dijes a $ 22.00 dólares cada juego, para poder aumentar su inventario y de esa manera satisfacer su demanda .

loans.use: Bracelets and sets of earrings and charms.

payments.comment: La cuota real es de $ 27.75  dólares lo pago el 30 de Enero no se pudo notificar a tiempo porque uno de los promotores esta de vacaciones y el otro estaba de subsidio por presentar problemas de salud.

loans.name: Peola

texts.en: Peola is 32 years old and married with two kids. She applied for this loan in order to buy inventory, such as perfumes, shoes, clothes, and sunglasses for her flea market stall. She also makes and sells Samoan cocoa in order to supplement her income. She is happy to be able to carry enough inventory to fill up her stall and hopes to stay a long time in SPBD’s loan program because her business is her only means of financial support.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her flea market stall and supplies for her Samoan cocoa business

loans.name: Fuli

texts.en: Fuli L. is a fifty-three-year-old mother of seven children. She is one of the oldest members of the loan programme and she is now on her fourth loan. She runs a farm and it is improving every year in size and income. Fuli has sons who go out to sea for fishing six days of the week which is a welcome additional source of income for the family. She plans to use part of this loan for improvement of her house and she is working hard on her farm as well.

loans.use: To buy tools and supplies for her farm and also for home improvements

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Ghana is the world’s second largest producer of cocoa. While most of the crop is exported to make chocolate, Abena, 45, uses cocoa pod, baking soda, and palm oil to make soap locally. She sells two main types of soap, Alata and Azuma blow. Alata is a Twi word for Nigerian, because the soap originated from Nigeria. Azuma is a famous boxer. Supposedly this soap can combat any laundry stain like Azuma combats his opponents.

Abena has 23 years of experience making soap. Her soap is so popular, that every time she makes it, it sells out in about a week. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase more raw materials to make more soap, since people in the market are demanding it.

Other than expanding her store, Abena is using her profits to complete her home. Currently she lives in a half-built house with her husband and seven children. Most of the rooms are incomplete and uninhabitable.

Abena is a leader of the lending group, The Believers. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount

loans.use: To purchase oil, charcoal, baking powder, and cocoa pods.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia, 30, has been in the Mankessim market for over 10 years now. Initially, she was selling cosmetics, but soon realized that cloth and dressmaking material has a higher demand at the market so she switched over. Her goal is for her store be the purchasing center for dressmaking material, such that people from all the neighboring towns will come to the market for her products.

Sometimes Patricia lets her brother take care of her store so that she has time for her 10-year-old daughter. Patricia balances between being a single mother and a business owner.

Patricia is a member of the lending group in the Mankessim market. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: Purchase zippers, thread material, and other dressmaking materials

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca sells large quantities of eggs in a store near the busy Mankessim market. She started the store with $200 of her own money 13 years ago and now her profits are about $200 a week.

Rebecca will use her loan to purchase more eggs and egg containers. She tries to purchase her eggs from the local farms, but sometimes they do not produce enough, so she has to by them from a distributor. Her goal now is to diversify her products, so she does not have to depend on the eggs. She would like to carry chicken feed, pillows, and chop boxes (used for street vendors to store food).

Rebecca is a member of the lending group, Adom Hen. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount

loans.use: To purchase eggs and egg containers

loans.name: Máxima

texts.en:
Máxima is an honest and very respectful woman in her community.  She is known in the town as a positive, assiduous and hard-working woman.  For almost two years, she has been selling vegetables.  Within her house, where she runs the business, people go to acquire goods such as carrots, manioc, yams, beetroot and so forth.  Fortunately, Máxima doesn´t have to go outside the town to get products since her husband has some fields and cultivates the vegetables.  Currently, she makes a weekly profit of $130.00.

The entrepreneur wants to enlarge the business and attract more clients.  She plans to rent a locale where she will run the business.  That will help customers more conveniently make their purchases.  Her business will also be more competitive, since clients like to feel comfortable when they go to a store to buy goods.  Máxima also plans to add new products to the business.  She says that before long, she will start to sell foodstuffs like bread, flour, rice, beans and spices.

With the loan requested, Máxima will purchase the new goods she will add to her business.  The other part of money will be invested in the rental of the new locale where business will be run.  Additional income will greatly help the entrepreneur to improve her economic situation, and keep fending for her four children.  Máxima has a good credit history.  She has already taken a loan from FSMA and, responsibly, she has repaid it.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables to supply a general store and rent a small locale to run the business.

loans.name: Yohanny Laurencia

texts.en:
Yohanny is a 28 year old, single woman.  She has two boys and a girl, aged 12, 11 and 8 respectively.  All the children attend school.

Yohanny dedicates herself to the sale of women's and children's clothing.  She has been running this business for more than three years.  This activity is her principal source of income, and through it, she provides food and education for her children and pays for her rented house.

Six months ago, the entrepreneur took a loan from FSMA because supplies had been running low in her business.  With the funds, she purchased clothing in bulk which she sold succesfully.  The loan helped her to give a new ´giro´ to the business and she was able to make a lot of profits and repaid the loan in due time.  She also opened a bank account and learned to save money for any unforeseen event.  Currently, she is operating her business in a small location that she could rent.

Yohanny is requesting a second loan to buy more clothing in bulk to sell during the Christmas period.  She will offer the goods at very low prices, so that more people can get to know her business and possibly become part of her numerous loyal customers.  Her income will also be increased, and her profit margin improved.

loans.use: Purchase of brand new women's and children's clothing to sell during the Christmas period.

loans.name: Ubalda De La Cruz

texts.en:
Ubalda is 39 years old and married with six children - four girls and two boys.  All of her children attend school.  Her husband works for a construction company.

Ubalda is an untiring woman.  She runs a small store, which she started five years ago.  She sells women's clothing, silver-plated jewelry, cosmetics and beauty products.  She gets the products in the captial, Santo Domingo, where she goes twice a month.  Currently, her business is very successful and she has a well established clientel.  She mostly sells the goods from her house, but on weekends she goes to sell in the surrounding areas.  Her monthly profit reaches the sum of $500.00. 

Ubalda is requesting a loan to purchase large amounts of products in order to increase her sales volume.  Getting products wholesale will help her saving money since she will considerably reduce the number of trips she makes outside the town to get the goods. 

This will be the second loan the entrepreneur will get from FSMA.  Five months ago, she took a loan from our organization to supply her business.  She used the funds wisely, could reach the goals she established and repaid the loan on time.  Given this second loan, Ubalda will be in a condition to make her business progress and will be on her way to fulfilling her dream, which is to have a big store.

loans.use: That second loan will be used to purchase cosmetics, jewelry and beauty products to supply the entrepreneur's business.

loans.name: Luisa Fidelina

texts.en:
Luisa's business is selling tablecloths and bedsheets.  Through this activity, she makes a living and cares for her unique 4 year old daughter.  She is 27 years old and is single.

Luisa has to go outside of her community to get the goods she sells.  Two times a month she goes to Elías Piña - a frontier province with Haiti - to buy products very cheaply.  She operates her business within her own house and sometimes she goes in the surrounding areas to offer the tablecloths door-to-door.  

This businesswoman hopes her activity can grow, and that she can attract more customers.  She needs funds to buy more products to supply her business.  Luisa had already shown herself to be a good example of a responsible person.  She has already taken a loan from FSMA, which she paid back in due time.  Additional income will help Luisa keep operating her business and working for the sake of her daughter.

loans.use: Funds will be used to buy tablecloths and bedsheets to supply the entrepreneur's business.

loans.name: Luaono

texts.en: Luaono is a 43-year-old woman who is married with four kids. She applied for this loan (her second) in order to restock her shop and she hopes she can improve business by increasing her inventory. Her first loan was used to start up the shop. She hopes to further expand the shop with future loans and hopes to learn to become a better businesswoman.

loans.use: To restock her small shop

loans.name: Vitolina

texts.en: Vitolina has been a member of Sagafili Mulifanua Center for a long time. She is the secretary of the Center and she is one of the most honest and faithful members of the Center. Vitolina is on her fifth loan and she is doing well with payments. Vitolina grows taro and bananas on her farm, which covers about four acres of land. She goes to the market three days a week where she can earn about 150 Tala (US$ 60) per day. She hopes to grow this business which is why she is applying for this loan to upgrade her equipment.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and tools for her farm and also for renovating her house

loans.name: Selepa

texts.en: Selepa S. comes from the village of Mulifanua. She is in her thirties and she is still active and hard-working. Selepa has five children and she is supporting them through school. Mulifanua is one of the richest parts of Upolu Island. Families living in this part of the island mostly fish for a living. Selepa’s husband goes fishing six days a week, if the weather is good. This would mean that Selepa can go to the market six days a week to sell the catch along with the crops from her farm. She can usually make 100 Tala (US$ 40) a day at the market. She is looking forward to receiving more loans in the future so she can buy a fishing boat.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear for her husband and supplies for their farm

loans.name: Faanuu

texts.en: Faanuu T. is a young mother from the village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She just joined SPBD’s loan program recently and she is applying for her first loan. She runs a pig farm and hopes to expand the farm with her loan. The farm has been in her family for many years. Faanuu is hard-working and active and this is the first time she has ever been able to borrow money. She hopes to pay off the loan quickly so that she can receive another one in order to make improvements on her house and to expand the farm even more.

loans.use: To buy wiring, fencing, and iron roofing for her pig sty

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina M. is a young mother from the village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She has a vegetable garden of cabbages, tomatoes, beans, cucumbers and pumpkins. She also sells taro, taamu and bananas at the Fugalei Market (the main market in town) and occasionally in her village when there is a surplus. She has been using her previous loans solely on the business but she plans to use this loan to renovate her house as well as for school fees for her children. Rosalina is looking forward to more loans from SPBD and she is very thankful for being able to support her family.

loans.use: to renovate her house as well as for school fees for her children

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: BEATRICE CHEPKOECH C. is aged 39 years. She is married with five children all schooling. Her husband is a tea farmer in Kericho District. Beatrice also takes care of her elderly parents. She never had the chance of attending any school because the Kalenjin culture was against girl child education. Beatrice is a business minded lady and 7 years ago she realized that her husband meagre income could not support the education of her children, its on this background that she started her own business of selling cereals in Liten market. After undertaking a business training conducted by Ebony Foundation, she is now able to manage her business well. The demand for her products has also greatly increased and sometimes she runs short of stock, to counter this she needs to double her reorder level. She is therefore requesting for a loan of US$ 1200 which she intends to spend as follows US$ 1000 buy 60 bags of dry maize and US$ 200 buy 10 bags of beans. Beatrice is hard working and she will repay the loan.

loans.use: to increase her current stock level

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her current stock level

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.ru:
Bahodur A., 27, is married and has 2 children. Bahodur’s main business is cattle farming and sales. He has been in business for 4 years. Bahodur A. plans to use this loan to purchase several animals, feed and sell them every 40-45 days. After sale, Bahodur plans to purchase a new batch of cattle and use the profits to sustain his family. He plans to repay the loan with 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Азамов Баходур, возраст – 27 лет, образование среднее, женат, имеет 2-х детей. Основной вид деятельности которым занимается клиент это разведение и продажа крупного рогатого скота. Этим видом деятельности он заниамется уже в течение 4 лет. На полученый кредит клиент планирует несколько голов крупного рогатого скота, который после откормки, через каждые 40-45 дней будет продаваться. После продажи он планиркет приобретать новую партию скота, а прибыль используьет для содержание семьи, так как других источников дохода лу него нет, в связи с отсутсвием рабочих мест с хорошей заработной платой. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase and sales of cattle

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Nguyen Thi T., 35 years old, makes mat to earn a living. She also raise 3 pigs to increase her income. She has 3 small children, from 4 to 10 years old, all of them are going to school. She looks a bit older than her real age due to all these years trying to make ends meet. When TYM Fund (Kiva partner) started to give out loans in her commune, Mrs. T. discussed with her husband and decided to borrow from TYM Fund. The loan has helped her a lot. This is sedge harvest season, so she wants to borrow 400USD to buy sedge when it is cheap.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Công việc hàng ngày của chị Nguyễn Thị Tươi, 35 tuổi, là dệt chiếu. Ngoài ra chị còn nuôi thêm 3 con lợn để tăng nguồn thu nhập. Nuôi 3 con nhỏ tuổi từ 4 đến 10 đang đi học trông chị già dặn hơn so với tuổi bởi những vất vả lo toan cho cuộc sống. Khi Quỹ TYM về với quê hương chị đã bàn bạc với chồng sử dụng vốn vay từ Quỹ và thấy phù hợp mang lại hiệu quả cao. Đang vào mùa thu hoạch cói chị đã đề nghị vay mức vốn 400USD để mua thêm nguyên liệu khi giá đang rẻ.

loans.use: Buy sedge to make mat

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi V., 43 years old, and her husband live in Quang Xuong district, Thanh Hoa province. In her province, almost everybody relies solely on the rice fields for their livings. If one wants to earn extra money, they have to work for someone else. Besides working on the rice-field, Mrs. V.’s husband also works as a construction worker. Mrs. V. herself makes wooden basket to increase her family income. These jobs help her life less difficult. She wants to borrow 450USD to buy more pigs and chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị V., 43 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Ở vùng quê chị đang sinh sống công việc chủ yếu của mỗi gia đình là làm ruộng. Nếu muốn có thêm thu nhập thì phải đi làm thuê. Chồng chị đã không vất vả, ngoài công việc đồng áng anh còn đi xây kiếm thêm tiền. Chị cũng là người siêng năng nên nhận thêm việc làm thúng để tăng thu nhập. Có nghề phụ kinh tế gia đình đỡ vất vả hơn. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị đề nghị vay mức 450USD về mua thêm lợn gà để chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Buy pigs, chickens

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. looks younger tH. other women at the age of 46. Her three children, from 16 to 21 years old, have helped her make mats to increase her family income. Her husband, 46 years old, helps her buy sedge and breed pigs and poultry. The loan from TYM Fund (Kiva partner) increases her family income significantly. She uses this fund to buy sedge or feed her pigs and poultry. The profit from selling mats is used to pay the weekly repayment. Now she would like to borrow 400USD to buy sedge to make mat.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Ở tuổi 46, chị Nguyễn Thị Hán trông có vẻ trẻ hơn tuổi. 3 người con của chị tuổi từ 16 đến 21 đã cùng chị dệt chiếu, đi làm thêm tăng nguồn thu cho gia đình. Chồng chị năm nay 46 tuổi ngoài việc thu mua nguyên liệu (cói) anh còn chăn nuôi thêm lợn gà. Những đồng vốn vay từ Quỹ TYM giúp kinh tế gia đình chị nâng lên rõ rệt. Vốn vay về đầu tư được sử dụng mua cói, hoặc chăn nuôi lợn gà, nguồn hoàn trả từ việc dệt chiếu. Hiện tại chị đề nghị vay mức vốn 400USD để mua thêm cói dệt chiếu phát triển kinh tế gia đình.

loans.use: Buy sedge to make mat

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Pham Thi M., 56 years old, and her husband live in Quang Xuong district, Thanh Hoa province. Her three children all have their own families now. Her husband Dan is a disabled veteran, but his health is still very good. So he often helps her with her weekly loan repayment. They raise pigs and make wooden baskets, and their income is pretty stable. This time she would like to borrow 325USD to buy more pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị Miên năm nay 56 tuổi sống cùng chồng tại Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Ba người con của anh chị đều đã trưởng thành và có gia đình riêng. Là bộ đội về hưu bị thương tật 3/4 nhưng trông anh Dạn, chồng chị vẫn còn khoẻ mạnh. Công việc hàng ngày của hai vợ chồng là chăn nuôi đàn lợn ngoài ra còn làm thêm nghề đan thúng thu nhập cũng ổn định. Được hỗ trợ trong việc hoàn trả tuần từ phía chồng nên việc vay vốn của chị Miên gặp nhiều thuận lợi. Chị đang đề nghị vay mức vốn 325USD về để mua thêm vài con lợn và sẽ bán khi được giá.

loans.use: Buy pigs.

loans.name: Trinh Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trinh Thi H., 37 years old, lives with her husband, 44 years old. They have 3 children who are going to school. Everyday she makes mats, while her husband buys mats from other households and sells them at the market. This job requires a pretty large amount of money. For 5 years, TYM Fund (Kiva partner) has given loans to Mrs. H. to buy sedge and mats. Her loan increases in each loan cycle, so as her family income. She would like to borrow 450USD to buy sedge mats.

Translated from Vietnamese by PH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trịnh Thị Hương năm nay 37 tuổi còn chồng chị 44 tuổi. Họ có 3 người con đều đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Công việc hàng ngày của chị là dệt chiếu còn anh đi thu mua chiếu từ các hộ gia đình khác và đem ra chợ bán lẻ. Việc này đòi hỏi một số tiền tương đối lớn. Để có tiền mua nguyên liệu và thu mua chiếu, chị Hương đã đến với Quỹ TYM từ 5 năm nay. Số vốn được vay tăng dần theo số năm tham gia, kinh tế gia đình cũng nâng lên rõ rêt. Vòng vốn này chị Hương xin vay 450USD cho chồng đi thu mua chiếu tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.

loans.use: Buy sedge mat

loans.name: Lydia

texts.es:
Lydia A. is a woman who has struggled for her three children. After working for a long time, her husband left her with her three children and she was forced to ask her mother to take care of them while she worked to provide for them. However, after some time, her mother passed away and Lydia had to quit her job to take care of her children. She, then, started to clean houses and after some savings, she bought some shoes to sell. With great faith, she started selling shoes little by little. Currently, she has more customers than before. Her children are married and Lydia is now alone.

However, life goes on. She desires to have some tranquility and peace at this stage in her life after going through many life troubles and pains, which she has overcome for her children. Her business is the only incentive that she has to make most of life, and she is fully aware that it is worth all her efforts. Thus, she is requesting a loan of $375, which will be paid off in installments over 3 months. Lydia will buy more shoes for the coming winter season and to offer more product variety to her customers. With your help, Lydia will be able to have hope and happiness in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Lydia A. una mujer que ha luchado por sus tres hijos. Después de haber trabajado por un largo tiempo, su esposo que aun vivía la abandonó, (actualmente finado) con sus tres hijos y ella tuvo que decirle a su mamá que le cuidara a sus hijos mientras ella se iba a trabajar para sacar dinero para mantenerlos. Sin embargo, al cabo del tiempo, la mamá murió, y fue así como Lydia tuvo que dejar de trabajar para ir a su casa y cuidar a sus hijos, comenzó por limpiar casas para poder sacar dinero, y después con unos ahorros, fue comprando zapatos para vender, y con mucha fe comenzó a vender poco a poco zapatos. Actualmente ya tiene más clientas. Y sus hijos ya se encuentran casados y Lydia quedó sola.

Sin embargo la lucha por la vida, sigue y ella desea tener tranquilidad en esta etapa de su vida, puesto que tuvo muchos problemas que enfrentar y sin embargo sacó adelante a sus hijos. Su negocio es el único incentivo que tiene para disfrutar de la vida y saber que todo lo que hizo valió la pena. Por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $375 para pagarlos en un plazo de 3 meses, con este dinero Lydia comprará más zapatos de temporada de invierno y así tendrá algo que ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Lydia podrá tener una esperanza de vida que le permita ser feliz.

loans.use: to buy winter shoes

loans.name: Mario Alberto

texts.es:
Mario Alberto is a young man who understands life and knows that in order to move ahead, he has to work hard. Mario is studying engineering, but tuition is expensive and his family is unable to afford it since his father's salary is very low and Mario has two other siblings who are also students. To pay for his tuition costs, Mario bought clothes and sold them to his friends, and little by little, he soon made some money. After some time, he had the opportunity to obtain a mobile stall to use on the weekends. This is how he opened his business and currently, he has some customers.

However, he needs to buy merchandise for the winter season. Thus, he requests a loan of $925 that he is certain will be paid in installments over 6 months. With this loan, Mario will be able to have a well-stocked inventory of winter clothing. With your help, Mario will be able to sell these clothes and have the resources to eventually become an engineer.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Mario Alberto es un joven que sabe lo que cuesta la vida, y que para poder salir adelante se tienen que esforzar mucho. Mario está estudiando ingeniería, sin embargo los gastos de la escuela son mucho, y su familia no le puede pagar esto, puesto que el sueldo de su papá es muy bajo y Mario tiene otros dos hermanos que están estudiando y necesitan salir adelante. Para poder pagar sus estudios Mario compró ropa y la ofreció a sus amigos, y poco a poco iba adquiriendo dinero, después de un tiempo se le presentó la oportunidad de obtener un local los fines de semana en un mercado rodante, y fue así como comenzó por abrir su negocio. Actualmente ya tiene unos clientes.

Sin embargo, necesita comprar mercancía para la temporada de invierno, por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está seguro podrá pagar en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Mario podrá surtir de ropa para la temporada de invierno. Con tu ayuda Mario podrá tener qué vender en esta temporada y así tendrá dinero para poder ser un ingeniero.

loans.use: to buy winter clothing

loans.name: José Alfredo

texts.es:
As a boy, Jose Alfredo learned from his parents that a grocery store, if properly managed, can afford one a good living. He has opened his own store and counts on the income to finance his studies at the university. He also works part time in construction. Between the store, the construction work and his homework, Jose works very hard to get ahead. At this time, he would like to buy more merchandise to stock the store and better serve his customers. He is asking for a loan of $325 which he promises to repay within 3 months. With your help, Jose Alfredo can finish his studies and find success.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

José Alfredo, es un hombre que lucha por salir adelante. Desde que estaba pequeño sus papás se dedicaron a los abarrotes, y el fue viendo que este negocio sabiéndolo manejar dejaba muy buenas ganancias. Es por esto que José decidió seguir el ejemplo de sus padres y poner su propio negocio de abarrotes que lo está sacando adelante para poder terminar de estudiar una carrera. Actualmente aparte de estudiar, y de tener la tienda de abarrotes trabaja medio tiempo en una constructora, y se divide el tiempo para poder realizar todas sus tareas. Esto habla de la lucha y la fuerza que tiene para salir adelante.

Sin embargo José está buscando crecer un poco su negocio al comprar más mercancía para poder tener más que ofrecer a sus clientes. Por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $325 para pagarlos en un plazo de 3 meses y con este dinero José piensa comprar más mercancía para ofrecer más y mejores productos a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda José podrá terminar su carrera y ser un hombre de bien.

loans.use: To stock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es:
After suffering an injury that left his motor control impeded Marcelino began making piñatas. The craft has allowed him to continue to support his family rather than be a burden to them. He and his wife have made a business of it and work very hard to succeed. The busy holiday season is fast approaching and they have many requests for piñatas. Marcelino is asking for a loan of $650 to buy materials and he promises to repay the loan in six months. Marcelino is counting on your support.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

El señor Marcelino se empezó a dedicar a la fabricación de piñatas desde que tuvo un accidente que lo dejo con una discapacidad motora. Y sus ganas de salir adelante y ser una fuente de ingresos en lugar de ser un costo para su familia aprendió a fabricarlas para mantener los gastos económicos de su hogar, hoy con el apoyo de su esposa se han dedicado a este negocio.

Sin embargo la lucha continúa y desean crecer para la temporada de invierno puesto que con las posadas y las fiestas navideñas, las piñatas son muy solicitadas. Actualmente ya cuentan con varios pedidos para estos días, es por eso que esta solicitando un crédito de $650 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses, con este dinero Marcelino podrá comprar materia prima para poder fabricar las suficientes piñatas para vender en la temporada navideña. Marcelino tiene fe en que tu generosidad le podrá ayudar.

loans.use: To buy materials for making piñatas.

loans.name: Rosa Elva

texts.es:
Rosa Elva is a woman that struggles to provide stability for her family with a good attitude even under adversity. In 1982, Rosa's husband lost his job and was not able to find work. Because of this situation they both began to look for an option to be able to obtain income. So, with the little savings that they had, they bought a truck that they converted into a tow truck. Since then, this is the way that they have been earning a living.

However, the truck needs to have some work done and needs to be painted so that it gives a better impression. For this reason, Rosa is asking for a loan of $250 that she'll pay back in a term of 3 months. With this money she can repair and paint the tow truck. With your help, Rosa and her family will be able to provide better service to their clients and will therefore, be able to have more income to be able to pay for household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Rosa Elva es una mujer que lucha por que su familia se encuentre estable, y con buena actitud ante la adversidad. En 1982 el esposo de Rosa quedó desempleado, y al paso del tiempo no conseguía trabajo, fue así que comenzaron a buscar entre los dos, una opción para poder obtener ingresos, y fue así como con unos poco ahorros compraron un camión que adaptaron para ser utilizado como grúa. Y desde entonces es la manera en que obtienen sus ingresos.

Sin embargo, el camión necesita tener mantenimiento y pintarlo para que de una mejor impresión, es por esto que Rosa está solicitando un crédito de US $250 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 3 meses y con esto poder darle mantenimiento a la grúa y pintarlo. Con tu ayuda Rosa y su familia podrán dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes y por lo tanto podrán tener más ingresos para poder pagar los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Maintenance of a tow truck.

loans.name: Blanca Asela

texts.es:
Blanca traveled from the city of Veracruz to the city of Reynosa 10 years ago along with her family, looking for a better future. From the time she arrived until 6 years ago, she worked in a maquiladora and due to a tight budget, the business laid her off. She decided to start a business and invest some money in something that would help maintain her children, as she had just gotten divorced. This was how she began to buy merchandise to sell such as toys, plastics for the kitchen, serving trays, talcum powder, among other things. Thus she started her business and began to maintain the house and her three children.

However, she expects that during the Christmas season the number of customers will increase, and for this reason she is requesting a loan of $475, which she will repay over a period of 6 months. She will be able to supply Christmas merchandise, as the season is near, and in this way will continue to keep her business growing. With your help Blanca’s children will be able to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Blanca viajó desde la ciudad de Veracruz a la ciudad de Reynosa hace 10 años junto con su familia buscando un mejor porvenir. Y desde que llegó trabajó en una maquiladora hace seis años, y por falta de presupuesto en la empresa la despidieron y fue entonces donde decidió iniciar un negocio, invertir su dinero en algo que le dejara una ganancia para la manutención de sus hijos ya que se acababa de divorciar. Así fue como comenzó a comprar mercancía como juguetes, plásticos para cocina, charolas, talcos, entre otras cosas, para vender y a partir de esto comenzó su negocio y a sacado para mantener la casa y sus tres hijos.

Sin embargo para la temporada navideña se espera que los clientes vayan aumentando y es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagar en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero podrá surtir mercancía para la temporada navideña que ya esta cerca y seguir con el crecimiento de su negocio. Con tu ayuda Blanca podrá sacar adelante a sus tres hijos.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for the Christmas season

loans.name: Omar Zeus

texts.es:
Two years ago, Omar began driving a taxi in Reynosa and nowadays, he has regular customers that ask him to drive them around the city. His family motivates him to keep working hard and try get ahead with this job because he wasn't able to get a job anywhere else, since he only finished elementary school, and companies don't hire people with so little education.

However, his struggle is ongoing, and he has to take care of the car that allows him to be a taxi driver. For this reason, he is asking for a loan of $250 that he will pay back in a term of 6 months. With this money, Omar will be able to repair his taxi so that he can continue to be productive. With your help, Omar and his family can continue getting ahead and maintain the functionality of thier source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Hace dos años, Omar comenzó a ofrecer sus servicios como taxista, en Reynosa, y actualmente tiene ya cielotes que le piden los mueva por la ciudad. Su familia lo motivó para salir adelante por medio de esta actividad, ya que en ningún lugar le daban empleo puesto que estudió hasta la primaria y las empresas ya no contratan a personas con tan pocos estudios.

Sin embargo la lucha es constante, y tiene que cuidar el carro que le permite ser taxtista es por esto que está solicitando un crédito de $250 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses, con este dinero Omar podrá comprarle refacciones a su taxi, para que le siga dando productividad. Con tu ayuda Omar y su familia podrán salir adelante y mantener funcionando su fuente de ingresos.

loans.use: Taxi maintenance.

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 35 years old he has 4 children, all studying in schools. One of his children has asthma. He has a spare parts shop in Kirkuk and he has applied to get $1200 to purchase new spare parts and make new shelves, paint the shop and renovate it in order to increase his income and develop himself.

This entrepreneur is from a volatile region and repayment risk may be higher. Lenders should consider this when making this loan.

To protect his identity, this entrepreneur's name has been modified and his face has been obscured in the photo.

loans.use: Purchase new spare parts

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama sells a variety of foods, but mostly she carries bananas and plantains. She attributes her success to the fact that she is the only large-scale supplier of these products in her area. A few times a week, Ama travels to neighboring villages to purchase bananas and plantains. Then she lugs them back by carrying them into tro-tros (a packed Ghanaian bus, converted from mini-vans). Because of this tedious transportation process, many banana and plantain sellers in the area come to her for their stock.

Ama has three children. The youngest, 14, is in middle school, the second youngest, 19, is studying to become an electrician, and the oldest, 26, is finished school. She hopes to use the profits for their school fees and to build a house for her family. Currently they live in a compound with around 20 people.

Ama is a member of the lending group, Disciples. This group of 19 guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. The members sell various products in Cape Coast. They also offer each other support in their businesses. Support and peer pressure provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and plantains

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Three years ago Agnes was working as a seamstress, but the income was not enough to support herself and her 4 children, so she decided to start her own business making peanut butter. It was a good business to start because it required only a small amount of start-up capital. She fries the peanuts, and then takes it to the public mill to grind them. The only issue is the cost of the peanuts. She would like to buy peanuts in bulk to reduce the price. If she receives the loan, she will be able to buy two sacks of peanuts.

Agnes says that her goals are all strictly for her children to receive higher education. They are still in junior high and primary school, but Agnes already has plans for all of them to attend university.

Agnes is a member of an Obuasi lending group in the market. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Many of the members have businesses close to each other in the market and have developed strong relationships over the years. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of peanuts

loans.name: Farti

texts.en:
Farti, 48, owns a general store that serves a small community in Obuasi. This is Farti’s second loan. With her first loan, Farti increased her profits so much she was able to add slippers and sachets of potable water to her stock. This time Farti hopes to add rice, tomato paste, oil, and other food products. The Christmas season will be coming where it is tradition to cook and eat a lot of rice. If Farti generates enough profit, she will add cloth to her stock.

Farti was married once, but her husband left for Germany to work and she has never heard from him since. Since then, she has been taking care of her daughter, currently 32, by herself. Now she has 3 grandchildren and will be getting married to her fiancé soon.

Farti is a member of the lending group in Obuasi. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To expand her store by purchasing more rice, tomato paste, oil, and other food products.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
15 years ago Lydia O. decided to start selling palm oil at the Obuasi Market. Since then she has become one of the most popular palm oil sellers at the market. She has good relationships with her customers. Palm oil is a red and flavorful cooking oil. It used in many traditional Ghanaian dishes, such as red-red, fu-fu soup, and palava sauce.

Lydia will be using the loan to purchase palm oil in bulk. This will decrease her costs significantly. Eventually Lydia hopes to build up enough capital to become a palm oil wholesaler.

Lydia is a member of the lending group in the Obuasi market. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount

loans.use: To purchase palm oil in bulk

loans.name: Gita

texts.en:
Mrs. Gita M., a 37-year-old lady, lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in a single family with her husband, a son and two daughters.
Her husband, Mr. Man Bhakta M., is a carpenter. Her son is in school. Her older daughter is studying in grade 5 and younger daughter is in primary school.
Mrs. M. opened her poultry farm a few years ago. She sells chickens and eggs in her farm. Now she is requesting her second loan of Rs 15000 to buy chickens to expand her business. She wants to spend her income in providing a better education for her children.

loans.use: To buys chickens

loans.name: Purnabati

texts.en:
Mrs. Purnabati M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Raju M., is a carpenter and her son is studying in grade 2.
Mrs. M. opened her duck farm few years ago. She sells ducks and eggs in her locality. She chose this business because very few people are engaged in this work and income is satisfactory for her to cover her household expenses. 
Now she is requesting  her second loan of Rs15000 to expand her business by buying more ducks.

loans.use: To buy more ducks

loans.name: Ofah

texts.en: Ofah is a 42-year-old married woman. She lives with her son and her mother because her other children have married and live separately. Her business is selling clothes on credit. She has to work hard by herself because her husband passed away. She usually sells the clothing by going around to various places to get more customers. She earns $20 per day and really expects the $50 loan to expand her business by helping her to buy more clothes to sell. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Selling clothes

loans.name: Hindun

texts.en: Hindun is 45 years old and married. She produces and sells some cakes together with her husband. They usually earn $5 per day, and it's just enough to cover their daily needs. She requests $125 loan to expand her business and sell various cakes. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To produce more various cakes

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf K. is a 45-year-old man living with his wife and their three children in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He works at a fueling station (pictured). His family is very poor, but he and his wife have been able to give all of their children a good education because they work so hard. He engaged in sheep-breeding in his houseyard as most people do in the Azeri countryside. He wants to increase the number of his sheep, and thus increase his family income. For this purpose, Yusuf applied to the Normicro Beylagan Branch for a loan of $400.

loans.use: To increase his family income by increasing the number of sheep.

loans.name: Elyane

texts.en: Elyane G. is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Fuzuli City in Azerbaijan. Her family settled in Beylagan in 1993. She is selling fruits and vegetables with her mother in the Beylagan city bazaar. She wants to expand her business and because of this she needs a loan of $600.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Pulau Menjangan Group

texts.id:
“Pulau Menjangan” is an island in West Bali which is a tourist area for diving and snorkeling. A group of housewives in Karangsari village (West Bali) used the island’s name as its group name. Menjangan group is a group of village housewives who meet every week in the village hall for money saving and loaning activities or conduct cleaning activities in the neighborhood. This group is lead by Ni Nengah Suarniti with Ni Ketut Suwitri as the secretary and Ni Luh Warni as the treasurer. This group has 15 members. Besides the money saving and loaning activity, this group also runs pig farming business at their own houses. This business was not coordinated well so that they had not earned maximum profit. The livestock had not been treated and fed well due to lack of knowledge in pig farming. After getting consultations and counseling about group management and good ways of pig farming from Dinari, Menjangan group plans to raise high quality piglets and to buy good quality pig’s food so that they can produce pigs with quality that meets the market’s standard. Each person needs a fund of Rp. 1,400,000 (about $148) which will be used to buy 4 piglets that cost Rp. 250,000 (about $26) each and Rp. 400,000 (about $42) for the food expense. After raising the pigs for 5 months, the Menjangan group will sell the pigs at the same time. The marketing will be coordinated by Dinari so that the group will have good selling price and on-time payment. With better group management and knowledge, they feel quite optimistic that the business will go well and they can still run the money saving and loaning activities since the part of the profit is kept in the group savings.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

” Pulau Menjangan” adalah sebuah pulau di Bali barat yang merupakan kawasan wisata untuk diving dan snorkle. Oleh sekelompok ibu – ibu didesa Karangsari, Bali barat, nama itu kemudian dipakai untuk nama kelompok. Kelompok Menjangan adalah perkumpulan ibu – ibu didesa yang kegiatannya adalah melakukan pertemuan setiap minggu di balai desa untuk simpan pinjam atau untuk mengadakan kegiatan bersih –bersih dilingkungannya. Kelompok ini diketuai oleh Ni Nengah Suarniti, Sekretaris oleh Ni Ketut Suwitri dan Bendahara oleh Ni Luh Warni. Kelompok ini beranggotakan 15 orang. Selain kegiatan simpan pinjam, kelompok ini juga mengelola ternak babi dirumah masing – masing. Kegiatan ini belum terkoordinir dengan baik, sehingga mereka tidak mendapatkan hasil yang maksimal. Ternak mereka belum mendapat perawatan dan pakan yang memadai karena kurangnya akan pengetahuan yang baik akan beternak babi yang benar. Setelah mendapat pembinaan dan pelatihan tentang manajemen kelompok dan pemeliharaan babi yang baik dari Yayasan Dinari, kelompok Menjangan berencana untuk memelihara bibit babi jenis unggul dan membeli pakan yang berkwalitas sehingga akan menghasilkan babi yang sesuai dengan standar pasaran. Masing – masing orang membutuhkan dana Rp. 1.400.000.- dengan perincian, membeli 4 ekor bibit babi @ Rp. 250.000.- dan Rp. 400.000.- untuk biaya pakan. Setelah 5 bulan masa pemeliharaan, kelompok Menjangan akan menjual babinya secara bersamaan dengan dikoordinir Yayasan Dinari untuk pemasaran sehingga kelompok akan mendapat harga yang terbaik dan pembayaran bisa dilakukan tepat waktu. Dengan manajemen kelompok dan pengetahuan yang lebih baik, mereka optimis usaha mereka berjalan dengan baik dan kelompok bisa tetap berjalan dengan simpan pinjamnya karena sebagian dari keuntungan penjualan digunakan untuk pengembangan kas di kelompok.

loans.use: To purchase high quality piglets and pig's food

loans.name: Ni Nengah Seri

texts.id:
With a strong will to live, Ni Nengah Seri, a widow who just lost her husband, makes a living by raising pigs. With the initial capital of Rp. 500,000 (about $53), Ni Nengah Seri bought 2 piglets. After raising them for 4 months, they were ready to be sold. The food expense per day is Rp. 10,000 (about $1). Besides rice and rye chaff, Ni Nengah Seri also feeds the pigs with banana stems and leaves. The earned profit after 4 months is Rp. 320,000 (about $34) per pig. After deducting the food expense, the net profit can be used to cover her daughter’s elementary education. Ni Nengah Seri hopes that with the loan from Dinari, she can buy 5 more piglets and pig’s food.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan tekad yang kuat untuk menjalani hidup Ni Nengah Seri seorang janda yang sudah ditinggal mati oleh suaminya, menjalani hidupnya dengan memelihara babi. Dengan modal awal Rp. 500.000,- Ni Nengah Seri membeli 2 ekor anak babi untuk penggemukan. Setelah dipelihara selama 4 bulan anak babi siap untuk dijual. Biaya pakan yang diperlukan perhari Rp.10.000.- Disamping dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Ni Nengah Seri juga memberikan makanan tambahan berupa batang pisang dan dedaunan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh selama 4 bulan sebesar Rp. 320.000,- perekor. Setelah dikurangi biaya pakan, keuntungan yang diperoleh dipergunakan untuk membiayai 1 putrinya yang masih duduk dibangku SD. Harapannya dengan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari, Ni Nengah Seri akan membeli 5 ekor bibit untuk penggemukan dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig's food

loans.name: Ni Wayan Kondri

texts.id:
It’s not easy for Ni Wayan Kondri to live alone as his husband has died and she still needs to go through this life without losing hope. By starting pig farming business, Kondri has recovered little by little from her poverty. With initial capital of Rp. 1,000,000 (about $107), Kondri bought 3 small pigs that she raised for 4 months. The pigs turned out to grow quite well and ready to be sold. One pig can be sold at Rp. 800,000 (about $85). The net profit (after deducting the pig’s food expenses) is Rp. 85,000 (about $9) per pig per month. From this profit, Kondri realized that if she had more capital, the earned profit would increase. Currently, Kondri needs extra capital of Rp. 3,000,000 (about $320) for purchasing more small pigs and pig’s food. She hopes the business will grow faster and more profitable.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Menjalani hidup seorang diri tidaklah mudah untuk Ni Wayan Kondri karena setelah suaminya meninggal, Ni Wayan Kondri tetap harus menjalani hidup ini dan tidak boleh berputus asa. Dengan memulai usahA beternak babi, Kondri sedikit demi sedikit mulai bangkit dari keterpurukan ekonominya. Dengan modal awal Rp. 1.000.000,-, Kondri membeli bibit babi sebanyak 3 ekor, setelah dipelihara 4 bulan ternyata babinya berkembang dengan baik dan siap dijual. Perekor laku terjual Rp.800.000,-. Keuntungan yang diperoleh setelah dikurangi biaya pakan adalah Rp. 85.000.- perekor per bulan. Dari keuntungannya inilah Kondri melihat bahwa jika memiliki lebih banyak lagi modal usaha, tentulah jumlah keuntungan yang didapatpun bertambah.
