George M. is a 27 year-old man who is married with one child. He lives on the outskirts of Nairobi in a town called Mlolongo. He has no other dependents. In the year 2005, he was employed by a Property Management Company. His employment there didn’t last for long; unfortunately, the company collapsed and George had nothing else to do other than to go home. With the salary that he was earning, George had managed to save Ksh 20000 (USD 286) which he used to start a barbershop business. He used the money to buy a shaving machine.

After some time, he noticed that people had a problem communicating since not everybody owned a mobile phone. With the earnings that he made, he bought a community phone in order to curb this situation. The business thrived, but, due to a lack of funds to support the business, it almost collapsed. He used his own talents and skills of patience and hard work and started repairing spoiled mobile phones, selling blank CD’s and selling scratch cards. After a period of six months, his business started booming and customers started flowing into his shop. The problems that George faced after losing his job made him innovative.

George now wants to expand his business and wants to buy two shaving machines, one smoother, and also a photocopying machine. The total amount is $450. He believes that, if this loan is given to him, he will be able to boost his business and attract more customers. From the increase in profits, he will be able to better provide for his family and educate his child.

The repayment period for his loan will be 8 months.

loans.use: To purchase two shaving machines, one smoother, and a second-hand photocopying machine.

loans.name: Américo João

texts.pt:
Américo João M. is 45 years old. He lives with his wife and 7 children in Corumana in the district of Moamba in Maputo. He has a stand where he sells soft drink and groceries. He also works as a fisherman. He joined the credit program in June of 2006, his first loan was of 6.000mt. He is requesting a loan of 12.000mt to be repaid in 6 months. Américo wants to buy more goods for his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Américo João M. tem 45 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é pai de 7 filhos. Vive em Corumana no distrito da Moamba em Maputo. Tem uma barraca onde vende bebidas e alguns produtos de mercearia, para além de praticar a pesca.Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2006 com 6.000MT como 1º empréstimo. Vai tomar no presente ciclo 12.000MT para pagar em 6 meses com vista a compra de mais produtos para a barraca.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven N., age 27, works with her husband in the paddy fields growing crops, earning together about $3.20 each day. They have no children, but one of her sisters lives with them and works in a garment factory. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a water pump machine and dig a well for her water supply.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump machine and dig a well for her water supply.

loans.name: Soloman

texts.en:
Soloman has a retail store in which the largest part of his business is the selling of dry staples. He mostly sells rice, flour, sugar, salt. He sells Pakistani rice and Ugandan Rice. The flour is cassava flour and maize flour.  He also sells millet and sorghum. He also carries a few canned and boxed items. 
Soloman is married, 34 years old, and has four children. He also cares for two orphans. Almost all persons in shantytown districts care for orphans. These are usually children of deceased brothers or sisters. AID’s and malaria are the largest contributors to the deaths of young adults. Because of the limited amount of resources people have, often the orphaned children they care for cannot attend the schools that their own children attend. However, hey are equally loved, as this is generally seen as life in the community, not a burden.
Soloman has had his business for three years. He is requesting a loan of $475 so he can keep his supply of dry staples replenished, satisfy his customers and hopefully expand his business. This will help him care for his family.

loans.use: To purchase more 25-50kg sacks of flour, rice, etc. for his store.

loans.name: Shamama

texts.en: Shamama Q. is a 43 year old woman who raises her livestock in a small village in Saatli region of Azerbaijan. She is internally displaced person who fled to Saatli during the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict in 1993. She started her business in 1998 when she bought a milking cow. Now she is running a dairy business. She sells milk and yoghurt  to the local people and bazaar traders. Shamama is married and has 6 children. Big family means  always funds shortages. Difficult economic situations in her family pushed her to sell the cow, and buy a calf. Now she is planning to adjust her business and purchase more calves and start selling them for meat production. To reach her goal,  Shamama applied for 900 USD loan to purchase three calves.

loans.use: To purchase three calves.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mr. Ros P., age 55, works on a plot of farmland growing crops, making $2 per day. His wife works at a garment factory, earning $3 each day. They have two children who are also employed at a factory, making about $120 per month each. He would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase seeds and fertilizer for his crop to make his farm more productive. He hopes that his income level will increase when he can sell additional crops to the middleman. His wife is pictured with their son as Mr. Ros P. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer for his crop to make his farm more productive.

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Mrs. Khim S., age 35, works with her husband raising pigs and making medicinal wine. They earn together around $8 each day. They have three children: one is a garment worker making about $75 per month, and two are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a water pump machine to draw well water more efficiently, build a barn to house her livestock, and purchase better feed for her livestock. Her husband is pictured in the photo standing in front of her livestock as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump machine to draw well water more efficiently, build a barn to house her livestock, and purchase better feed for her livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a stock of paraffin.

loans.name: Armando Xavier

texts.pt:
Armando Xavier M. is married and father of 4 children. He lives in the district of Corumana in Moamba. He has a stand where he sells soft drinks and some groceries such as cookies, butter and matches. He also works as a fisherman. Armando joined the credit program in November of 2006, and his first loan was of 6.000mt. He is now in the 3rd cycle of the program and is requesting a loan of 15.000mt to be repaid in 6 months. Armando will use this loan to buy more goods for his stand.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Armando Xavier M. é casado e pai de 4 filhos. Vive em Corumana no distrito da Moamba. Tem uma barraca onde vende bebidas e refrigereantes, e alguns produtos de mercearia como pastas dentífricas, bolachas, manteiga, fósforos, entre outros.Para além deste negócio , tem barco e pratica pesca. Entrou para o programa em Novembro de 2006 com um empréstimo de 6.000MT. Vai para o 3º ciclo e vai tomar 15.000MT para pagar em 6 meses. Pretende aplicar este valor no aumento do stock da barraca.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mrs. Khiev T., age 47, works with her husband on her plantation growing crops, making around $4 each day. They have five children: three are employed at garment factory and two are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a cow to help her plow her field. This will lead to a greater output of crops and increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to pull a plow on the farm.

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en: Teymur R. is a 21 year old trader who owns a shop where he sells spare parts. His shop is in big demand by car enthusiasts in the  Imishli region. He is single and started his business in 2006. He has applied for a  700 USD loan to purchase modern spare parts and  move to a big, bright place. He also wants to enlarge his workplace. Teymur believes these improvements could attract more clients and increase his sales.

loans.use: Going to purchase modern spare parts

loans.name: Muen

texts.en: Mrs. Muen H., 70, is a widow and lives with her eight children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works on her piece of land growing mushrooms and generally earns around $5/day in revenue from selling the outputs to a middleman. One of her children is an electrician, another one is employed by a private company, and the rest work at a garment factory or are students. Mrs. Muen H. has applied for a loan to purchase a simple car for her son to operate his own business as a taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a simple car for her son to operate his own business as a taxi driver.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sin S., 33, is married with two school-aged children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She runs a stand at an open-air market selling a variety of fresh vegetables, earning on average around $2.43/day of profit. Her husband is employed by a private company as a driver, making about $3.33/day in revenue.

Mrs. Sin S. is humbly requesting a loan to help expand her inventory by adding more vegetables to meet the growing customer demand.

loans.use: To  help expand her inventory by adding more vegetables to meet the growing customer demand.

loans.name: Koim

texts.en: Mrs. Koim V. L., age 47, runs a stand from her home selling vegetables, earning around $2 each day. Her husband works as a carpenter, making on average around $2.50 each day. They have four children. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi to earn additional income for his family when he is not working at the carpentry shop.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike to run a moto-taxi business.

loans.name: Akutwala Ekino Lending Group

texts.en:
Tatoo is the chairperson for the Akutwala Ekino Lending Group in the Kyebando District of Kampala. She is the lady in the far left of the photo. Tatto is 35 years old and married with six children. She has operated her restaurant for two years. One day she hopes to be able to build some rental units. She will use this loan to continue buying foodstuffs for her restaurant. Tatoo serves typical Ugandan dishes such as matooke, cassava, posho, rice, beans, Irish potatoes, chicken and beef.

At Pearl, loans to groups are the most common. Through its long presence in Uganda, Pearl is able to identify villages that would benefit from microfinance loans. They contact village leaders, religious groups, etc. to see if there is a need and desire amongst villagers. If the need exists, they meet with businesses and begin a month or two of weekly meetings, educating business owners about the risks and benefits of such loans. If agreed, a lending group forms with chairperson, secretary and treasurer, voted in by members of the group. Members chose which businesses will qualify for loans and how much each qualified business member will receive as a loan. The added total becomes the group loan.

It is important that this is done by the group members because, as a group, they are all responsible for the repayment of the loan. One would not want a business in the group to default, because it can cost the other members. This type of peer pressure is very effective. Persons in groups create a very strong bond with each other. They are very supportive of each other and members have long histories in groups. Meetings are very business-like and the sense of empowerment is evident. Pearl meets weekly with the groups to answer questions, collect loan repayments and to offer continued education in finance.

loans.use: To purchase more matooke, posho, beans and cassava for her restaurant.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Mr. Vong P., age 46, works as a construction foreman, earning around $2.40 per day in revenue. His wife is a garment worker, making $1.80 per day. They have three children, two who are mechanics and one who is a student. He would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase mechanical tools and spare parts for their children’s business. This will increase revenue and benefit the entire family. His wife and younger daughter are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase tools for a mechanics business.

loans.name: Admiro Lacita

texts.pt:
Admiro Lacita M. is 37 years old. He lives with his wife and 3 children. He joined the credit program in June of 2007, and his first loan was of 5.000mt which he repaid without problems. Admiro sells plastic goods in his stand. He also sells clothes on the street. He is in the 2nd cycle and is requesting a loan of 8.000mt to be repaid in 6 months.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Admiro Lacita M. tem 37 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é pai de 3 filhos. Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2007 com um empréstimo de 5.000MT o qual reembolsou sem problemas. Vende diversos artigos de plásticos na sua barraca e também faz venda ambulante de roupa. Vai para o 2ºciclo e vai tomar 8.000MT para pagar em 6 meses com vista a reforçar os dois negócios .

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Aflatun

texts.en: Aflatun R.   is a 42 year old farmer who owns livestock in asmall village in the southern part of Azerbaijan, in the Saatli region. He is married and has three children. He works as a teacher in a local school and sells dairy products to the local bazaar traders. He and his wife learned how to make yoghurt and are very successful in selling  it also to the local people. His family needs in more financial sources than just teaching and selling milk and yoghurt.  To develop Aflatun`s business he needs more funds. He decided to expand his business and purchase four calves and sell them for meat production. He hasapplied for a1200 USD loan with a repayment period of 15 months. The estimated cost for one calf is 300 USD.

loans.use: To purchase four calves

loans.name: Sren

texts.en: Mrs. Sren S. M., age 38, runs a stand at a market selling clothes, making around $5 per day in revenue. Her husband is a recycler, selling the recyclable items he collects to the recycling company to earn about $4 per day in revenue. They have four children, two who help her with her business, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase more recycling items to resell for an additional profit. This will increase the income of her family and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase recyclable items to resell for a profit.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Mrs. Hem S., 47, is a mother of eight children and lives with her ailing husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To contribute to her family's income, Mrs. Hem S. runs a stand at a market selling Khmer food, rice, and porridge, making on average $7/day in revenue.

Some of her children are married and three are enrolled in school. Mrs Hem S. has humbly requested a loan to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Otto

texts.en:
Otto is the very cheerful owner the rather large, open air restaurant shown in the picture. Behind the plywood screen behind Otto is the kitchen. Several fires are going, each with pots. Save for the cutting table, everything is done on the floor. Women all leaning over pots for cooking or wash basins for dirty dishes. People do not bend down at the knees, they lean over at the waist.  Whether they are cooking, washing clothes, mopping the floor, they always bend at the waist. 

Otto is like a mother hen. Her staff loves her and all have much fun together. She is married with six children of her own, and she also cares for three orphans. Otto has been in the restaurant business for eight years. With her loan, she will buy foodstuffs for her restaurant. She serves typical Ugandan dishes of matooke, posho, cassava, bean, rice, chicken and beef.

loans.use: To buy more matooke, posho, cassava, beans, rice, chicken, beef, etc. for her restaurant.

loans.name: Jeyran

texts.en: Jeyran S.  is a 49-year-old farmer who sells dairy products and poultry in the  southern part of Azerbaijan, Bilasuvar region.  She is a dislocated person  who fled from Nagorny Karabakh to Bilasuvar during Azerbaijani-Armenian conflict in 1993. She is married and has 4 children. Poultry and meat are in high demand all across Azerbaijan and people use it  in every day life. Jeyran works very hard to keep her family in good condition, however it is not enough, because prices for products increase every year. As she and her husband are unemployed, selling milk, yoghurt, eggs and hens is not enough and she applied for  a 1200 USD loan to purchase 4 calves for an estimated price 300 USD each.

loans.use: To purchase 4 calves

loans.name: Linda Vasco

texts.pt:
Linda Vasco M. is 37 years old, she is a single mother of a son. She lives in the neighborhood of Fomento in Matola. She joined the credit program in September 2006 and her first loan was of 3.000MT. When she joined the program she was selling groceries but now she sells clothes and bed linens. She is in the 3rd cycle of the program and is requesting a loan of 8.000mt, to be repaid in 8 months. She plans on increasing her inventory.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Linda Vasco M. tem 37 anos de idade, é mãe solteira de um filho.Vive no bairo Fomento na Matola. Entrou para o programa em Setembro de 2006 com um empréstimo de 3.000MT. Vende roupa nova e roupa de cama.Quando entrou para o programa vendia produtos alimentares. Vai para o 3º ciclo e vai tomar 8.000MT para pagar em 7 meses com vista comprar mnais roupa para o seu negócio.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Kato

texts.en:
Kato sells fish which are caught in Lake Victoria. Lake Victoria is the second largest fresh water lake in the world and is just 20km from downtown Kampala. The major fish are the Nile Perch and Talapia. Talapia are native and the perch were introduced. 
Kato gets her fish from the fisherman. The fish are already smoked, dried and salted. Since there is no refrigeration, this is the only way to sell this product in the villages. Usually these fish are then steamed or stewed in a broth and are eaten in a hearty soup and is very tasty. 
Kato also sells a very small fish, about the size of a minnow. These are also dried by skewing about a dozen of them on a thin stick and left out to dry. They are sold by the stick and are used in a mix with g-nuts to make a delightful, high-calorie paste treat often spread on matooke. Children love it.
Kato has been buying fish from the fisherman for 20 years and has a very established clientele that purchases their fish from her. She will use her loan to buy more fish so she can supply more customers and to pay for transport of the fish.

loans.use: To buy more fish from the fisherman and to pay for transportation from Lake Victoria to her market.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has been in the Elmina Market for 8 years now. She sells canned vegetables, noodles, oil, sugar, and various ingredients from a table in the market. She hopes to use the loan to increase her stock and move into an indoor stall for her products. An indoor stall would provide a more secure environment and, more importantly, she would not have to spend her time packing and unpacking all of her products at the end and beginning of each day.

As a single mother, she feels a strong obligation to succeed in her business for her children. Her youngest son is in junior high school, and her two other children are in senior high school. All three children hope to attend university if Mary can financially support them. It is Mary's strongest desire to see all her three children through university as a single mother.

Mary is a member of the lending group, Nyame Beba of Elmina.

loans.use: She hopes to use the loan to get an indoor stall which is more secure and increase her stock of goods to sell for more profits.

loans.name: Ni Komang Winarti

texts.id:
Day to day Ni Komang Winarti works in her kiosk that she already run for 1 year. Her sales items are items of daily needs that are used by surrounding people, like: Coconut oil, rice, instant noodles, and other kitchen needs. By opening the kiosk, Ni Komang Winarti could help her husband I Ketut Suanta, who is only a tenant farmer. Usually Ni Komang Winarti bought her items from her supplier. Ni Komang Winarti already has many customers. Per day she could profit Rp50,000 (about US$5.25). This profit is a big help to family's daily income, and could support family's economic situation. From Dinari's loan, Ni Komang Winarti will add her sales items to be more complete and satify her customers.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Dalam kesehariannya, Ni Komang Winarti menekuni usaha warung yang sudah dijalani selama 1 tahun. Barang dagangan yang dijual berupa barang kebutuhan sehari – hari yang diperlukan masyarakat, seperti minyak kelapa, beras, mie instan dan kebutuhan dapur lainnya. Dengan membuka usaha warung, Ni Komang Winarti bisa membantu suaminya, I Ketut Suanta, yang hanya sebagai petani.Biasanya Ni Komang Winarti membeli dagangan di suplier yang sudah menjadi langganannya. Sudah banyak langganan yang dimiliki oleh Komang Winarti. Dalam satu hari menerima keuntungan Rp.50.000.- Keuntungan ini sangat membantu pendapatan keluarga setiap hari sehingga bisa menopang perekonomian keluarganya. Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, I Komang Winarti menambah barang daganganya sehingga lebih lengkap dan bisa memuaskan pelanggannya.

loans.use:
To buy items for sale

Membeli barang dagangan

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: I am a newly wedded girl called Abida from a small city Arifwala, Pakistan. I do not go out and work as it is not considered acceptable in the society I live in. My husband is a scrap dealer. He collects various used items and spare parts on his bicycle from different parts of the city. He then sells these things to various scrap yards in the city. At present, his income is very small. Therefore, he wishes to expand his business by buying a large amount of scrap items. Please lend him $200 for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase used goods in wholesale quantities

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude proudly calls herself a fashion designer. She is 41 and single with three children. She also cares for eight dependents. For the past three years, she has operated a storefront where she has two sewing machines. One is electric and one is manual, used when the electricity goes out. Her clients choose a pattern from one of the pattern books, then they select the material. When their choices are made, Gertrude quotes a price, which is often less than what the item would cost in a store. Sometimes a customer wants to buy a gomesi, or traditional dress. This is only sold as a custom-made garment and can be quite elaborate. 
There are different levels of tailoring shops in the villages. Some are simple, on the street: just a bag of scrap cloth, a foot-powered sewing machine, some thread and a bench to sit on. Others, like Gertrude's, have a storefront, with several sewing machines, a variety of cloth and embroidery to choose from and books from which to choose patterns. 
Gertrude learned this trade as a young girl, and it is very good for young girls to have a skill if they don't get formal education. Often in villages, it is considered more important that boys stay in school. Without a formal education, young girls become very vulnerable. So, learning a trade or skill which can be practiced in their village is vital. 
To become a tailor is usually a two-year course. During these two years, girls learn sewing skills, independence and self-esteem. The people that start these schools usually have a shop themselves and the classes are a labor of love for these young girls. Gertrude exudes confidence, a confidence born by learning a skill. With her loan, she will buy more cloth and embroidery for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth and embroidery for her business

loans.name: Chik

texts.en: Mrs. Chik N., 29, is married with one school-aged child and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To supplement her household income, she works selling various kinds of grocery products at home, earning around $3.16/day in revenue. Meanwhile, her husband is self-employed as a taxi-driver, making on average about $7.30/day in revenue. Mrs. Chik N. hopes this loan will help her to buy more products so that she can satisfy her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To expand her business so that she can satisfy her growing customer demand.

loans.name: Cherkez

texts.en: Cherkez S. is 39 year old  farmer who sells sheep for meat production. He is married, has 2 children and lives in the Saatli region. He has 8 years of experience in raising and selling sheep. The main  purchasers are local people, who purchase mutton for wedding parties and for holiday meals, and local bazaar traders. Breeding sheep is the only  financial source for his family and it is very hard to keep his family in good condition and to cover all their needs. He has applied for 1200 USD  to add to his farm livestock. This amount is for purchasing 10 additional sheep and two calves. The estimated price for one sheep is 60 USD and for one calf is 300 USD.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sheep and two calves

loans.name: Muniran

texts.en:
I request a loan of $300 for my husband’s business. He operates a catering company and provides food for various events. The wedding season has just begun here and my husband is receiving a large number of catering orders. However, he lacks the funds to purchase large cooking pots, which he requires urgently in order to meet these orders on time.
I am a mother of five, four boys and one girl. We wish to give them a secure financial future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking pots for catering business

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
For many young girls Roselyn’s school, Jewels High Fashion College, is a path of hope. The skills and self-esteem they learn will empower them with a trade that will make them self-reliant. It is hard to overstate the importance of young girls learning skills or trades that will allow them to create their own businesses.

Young girls are particularly vulnerable to sexual abuse, diseases caused by such abuse, unwanted pregnancies, and all the lack of opportunities that come from such consequences. The problems often start with families needing them to drop out of school to help at home. It is considered more important that boys stay in school. Once they drop out, their hopes and dreams easily fade away. In addition, there are no paying jobs in the villages. The only way for these girls to attain security may be to get pregnant. Therefore, the ability to learn a skill outside of formal education is vital. With a trade or skill, they can open a business and regain their sense of self.

This is where Roselyn has found her life’s work; a labor of love for young girls who need an opportunity in their villages. Not only does she give them a skill and the self-confidence to handle a business, but she makes sure that when they finish school, they own a sewing machine and enough material to open their door to their village clients. Roselyn has operated her business for ten years. She has day and night classes. She has 25 students and five sewing machines. With her loan, she will buy more machines so students do not have to wait to enter her school. Her dream is to open branches of her school in other villages. She is very energetic and a very loving individual.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines for her students.

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en: Eldaniz S. is a 34 year old trader who sells food products to the local people in the Saatli region, which issituated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He has seven years of experience in this field.  He has applied for 1200 USD to expand his trade business and to increase the variety of products he sells.

loans.use: To expand his trade business and enlarge number of products

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mussarat

texts.en: I am Mussarat B. from Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of three. I live with my family in a small rented house. I am a seamstress and I make clothes for my clients. My husband is a shoemaker and he makes men shoes. Eid is around the corner and this is the time when the sale for shoes and other items increases. My husband wants to do more business this season and we require a loan of $175 to buy leather and other related materials in bulk so that he can produce a larger variety of shoes. We hope to generate higher profits which we will save to build a house of our own.

loans.use: Buy leather and other stuff in bulk

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
Firuza A. is a very energetic and creative person. She has been selling clothes for over 5 years. From her profits, she has been able to add a room to her house for a food shop. She has 4 children and they are old enough for help her at the food shop.

She got her first loan from Microinvest in 2006, which she used to increase the variety of clothes to sell. Her sales were successful and with the profits, she purchased groceries to sell in her food shop. Her clothing stall is well known, and she sells her clothes quickly.

Firuza requests a loan from Kiva so she can buy two tables and eight chairs for her food shop and cafe, where her children can offer hot coffee and some baked goods.

loans.use: Furnish cafe

loans.name: Najma

texts.en: I am Najma B. from Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. I am 45, married and a mother of eight children. My husband is a shoemaker; he makes shoes and sells them to various shoe shops in nearby markets. My sons also help their father in the business. My sons feel that they need to expand their business and to produce a greater number of shoes. We would like a  loan of $350 to purchase leather, glue and other related materials in a large quantities.

loans.use: To purchase leather and other materials for making shoes in bulk

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en:
Tahir S. is a 34-year-old farmer who sells dairy products. He is a local farmer and lives with his wife in the southern region of Imishli. He has seven years of experience in selling milk, and making and selling yogurt. He likes his job and is very polite with every purchaser. Sometimes orders for dairy products are very high, like for 10-15 liters of milk. However Tahir's one cow gives only 5 liters of milk in a day.

Money that he has from selling dairy products just enough for food, so to expand his business he needs more funds. For the purpose of expanding his business he applied for 1200 USD to purchase one more milk cow for the estimated price of 700 USD, and for two calves, each for 250 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Meach

texts.en: Mrs. Meach L., age 53, is a garment worker, earning about $4 per day.  Her husband is a farmer, making less than $1 per day.  They have three children, one who is married and works selling gasoline, earning about $50 per month, and two who are unemployed.  She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to open a stand selling gasoline so her son has a permanent place to sell his gasoline, thereby drawing more frequent customers and increasing his income to benefit his family.  Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was unavailable at the time.

loans.use: To purchase a stand to sell gasoline.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: My name is Zainab B. from Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. I have been living in this city since my birth. I am married with 11 children. My husband operates a fruit stand in a nearby market and tries to keep fresh produce on his stall. His clients highly appreciate the high quality of produce on his stand. My eldest son recently started a plastic sheeting business; he buys these sheets from a wholesale market and then sells them to various clients in other markets. He now wishes to expand his business for which he requires a loan of $350. With this money he will buy bundles of plastic sheets in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase plastic sheeting in bulk

loans.name: Sadbarghon

texts.en:
Sadbarghon T. has been selling small household goods for over 3 years, in the J.Rasulov district of Khujand,Tajikistan. She loves her business very much, because it is interesting to help customers choose small items. She has a large assortment of goods and every day her stall is crowded.

Sadbarghon T. is an active client of Microinvest. For the coming holiday month, she wishes to purchase many fancy goods so she can take advantage of the holiday trade and increase her sales and profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more goods so she can increase sales.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to increase sales

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Mrs. Sreng P., age 43, is a widow and works raising pigs, earning around $1.50 each day.  She has 3 children, one who is a garment factory worker, earning around $2 each day, one who is a construction worker, and one who is a student.  She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase additional pigs to increase her livestock and build a small grocery store near her home to sell foodstuffs.  She is pictured with her daughter in their home.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and build a grocery store.

payments.comment: Congratulation!, Mrs. Sreng Phally has successfully paid off her loan early. She is really appreciative and thankful for your all micro-loans on her family.

loans.name: Oisha

texts.en:
Oisha R. has been selling in small household goods for over 7years, in J.Rasulov, Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. Every day she buys her goods from the wholesale market from Gulchehra Normatova. She has many customers, sells her good quickly, and has a profitable business.

She became a client of MLF Microinvest in 2003 and her first loan was for 300 somoni (about $87). During her partnership with MLF Microinvest, she established a reputation as a punctual and honest person. She requests a loan from Kiva to purchase more fancy goods to sell for the upcoming New Year holiday.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to sell for New Year holiday

loans.name: Thaong

texts.en: Mrs. Thaong P., age 45, works in her rice paddy growing crops, earning around $2 each day.  Her husband is a taxi- driver, making about $6 per day of profit.  They have three children who are married and live separately.  She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase pigs to raise for additional profit.  She plans to use any remaining funds to help fix her husband’s taxi so it is more reliable.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to raise and resell, and to repair a taxi.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: I am a mother of five children, all of whom study at a local school. I also work in the cotton fields as a daily wage laborer to support my family's income. I am requesting a loan for $300 so that my husband can expand his vegetables business which he operates in the food market of the city. He currently earns approximately $200 per month and now wishes to enlarge his stall and keep a greater quantity and variety of vegetables at his stand.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables

loans.name: Rani

texts.en: I am Rani B.. I am married with nine children, six girls and three boys. I live with my family in a small city called Arifwala, Pakistan. I do not work because my children are small and I have to take of them at home. My husband is the only breadwinner of the family and he operates a used clothes business. He is an honest and a hardworking entrepreneur. A year ago, he acquired a loan for his business which turned into better profits. Now he requires another loan of $350 to expand his business further and to help us give a better life to our children.

loans.use: Expand used clothes business

loans.name: Te You

texts.en: Mrs. Te You S., age 54, is a housewife who also grows rice crops.  Her husband is a blacksmith and also works digging wells, earning around $8 each day.  They have eight children, some who are married and some  who are students.  She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase a rice-grinding mill to more efficiently separate the rice from the husk and not have to perform the process manually, which involves crushing the rice husks with her feet.  This mill will increase the output she can sell.

loans.use: To purchase a rice-grinding mill.

loans.name: Mouk

texts.en: Mrs. Mouk S. H., 31, is married and lives with her husband and four school-aged children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.  She runs a stand at an open-air market selling a variety of fresh vegetables, making on average $4.80 /day in revenue.  Her husband works on his rice paddy growing rice crops and some kinds of vegetables, earning around $3.33/day of income.  Mrs. Mouk S. H. is humbly requesting a loan amount of $800 to purchase more vegetables to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to expand her inventory

loans.name: Walayat

texts.en: My name is Walayat B. from Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of six children: two boys and four girls. My husband runs a shoe store and has done so for a number of years.  He has developed a strong client base through his polite customer service and fair pricing. He now wishes to expand his business for which, we would like a loan of $175 to purchase ladies shoes in bulk for his store. He hopes to generate higher profits this year at Eid ( a Muslim religious festival), which will take place next month.

loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk for her store

loans.name: Miraga

texts.en: Miraga is a 44-year-old trader who owns a small shop in the southern region of Imishli. He is married and has five children. He sells food and some textiles like suits and dresses. He has thirteen years of experience trading. During these years he has had good times and bad times, but for about five years he has had stable income from his shop. Covering family needs is very hard considering that fact that Miraga has big family, and he sees only one way to improve conditions of his family. He wants to diversify the number of products in his shop to attract additional funds. He applied for 1200 USD to improve his shop.

loans.use: To improve his shop and diversify

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Mrs. Moeun R. is a housewife and her husband is a barber, earning $4 per day.  They have eight children, some of whom are married and live away from home, some who are hairdressers, and two who are students.  She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase hairdressing tools for her children’s business and to buy a motorcycle for her family’s transportation.  Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing tools and a motor-bike.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina is an experienced entrepreneur from Novomoskovk, Ukraine. For the past ten years she has helped to support her family by operating a small market sales business. She currently sells sports apparel and men’s jackets from a little kiosk at the central market in Novomoskovsk. There is a good demand for these products, and Angelina’s business has been very profitable. She makes about $1400 in a typical month. Angelina would like to continue growing her business and eventually would like to open her own small store facility.

Angelina has requested a loan of $1000 so that she can purchase new inventory and work to attract new customers. She has proven to be a good loan client with Nadiya Ukraine, and we are happy to continue assisting her in reaching her business goals.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: I am Sakina B. and am the mother of four children. All of my children attend a nearby school except one who is not of school-going age yet. My husband operates a woolen shawls and blankets business. He started this business by acquiring a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution. His business has been growing gradually since then. Now we require another loan of $175 to further improve our business. We plan to buy a large amounts of shawls and blankets, as their demand has risen in the winter season that has just begun.

loans.use: Buy shawls and blankets for the business

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en: Mahammad is a 47-year-old farmer who raises livestock for sale. He lives in Varkhand village of the Saatli region with his wife and has 4 children. He started his small business in 1995 when he first borrowed money and purchased calves for meat. It brought good income and helped to cover his family needs. But still his poverty has pushed him to broaden his business by purchasing additional calves and a milk cow. For this purpose he applied for 1200 USD. This amount will buy one milk cow for 700 USD and 2 additional calves.

loans.use: Going to purchase one milk cow and two calves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en: Angeline is a 43-year-old widow. Her husband died in the year 2000 due to HIV-related illness. She lives with her seven children, four of whom are in school. After her husband's death, she ventured into three businesses in order to sustain herself and her children. She sells cereals, new clothes, and fish, especially sardines ("omena" in the local language). She attends the Luanda market where displays and sells her merchandise on Mondays and Thursdays, the locals' market days. With the US$700 loan, she plans to buy a large stock of cereals and new clothes which will be in high demand during the Christmas season.

loans.use: Purchase stock of cereals and new clothes for sale.

loans.name: Maftuna

texts.en:
Maftuna has been selling groceries for over 3 years. She is married and has 2 children. Her business is located in J.Rasulov, Tajikistan.

Every day she buys her goods from local confectionery workshops and other suppliers who carry products from Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Her business is very profitable.

Maftuna became a client of MLF Microinvest in January 2007, and her first loan was for 350 somoni (about $100). During her partnership with MLF Microinvest, she established a reputation as a punctual and honest person. She is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is divorced and is raising her son on her own. She supports herself with a small business selling women’s clothing at the bustling outdoor central market in Novomoskovsk, Ukraine. Starting her own business and becoming a market vendor was the best option Galina had when she needed to earn money. She has been selling now for five years. In a typical month she makes about $600 in profit. Galina hopes to expand her business in the future by opening another sales location. For many market vendors like Galina, opening additional sales kiosks is the best way to increase their overall income and help ensure long-term sustainability.

Galina has requested a six month loan of $500 to help purchase new inventory. This loan will help Galina meet customer demands and make a good profit over the busy year-end season.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Lik

texts.en:
Mrs. Lik M., age 50, is employed at a private company earning around $3 per day. Her husband works the land surrounding their home to grow bananas, earning about $3 per day. They have no children. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to build a fence to protect the bananas produced on their land, as well as to purchase additional banana trees.

Mrs. Lik M. is the approved borrower and has requested this loan to expand her husbands’ crops, as they share the profit in this family run business.

loans.use: To purchase more banana trees and build a fence to protect the crop.

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Mrs. Khat Y., 62, is married with five children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home cooking food for her members, while her husband is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver, earning around $1/day of profit. Moreover, two of her children are blacksmiths, another one is a driver, and the rest of whom are unemployed. Mrs. Khat Y. hopes to use this loan to purchase cows to breed and the leftover of the money is to purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver

loans.name: Wilfrida

texts.en: Wilfrida (smiling in the photo) is a 43-year-old widow who lives with her 7 living children at Sinaga Siaya Kenya. Her husband died in 1999. She initiated her fish-selling business in 1996. Wilfrida buys omena (a type of fish which is the locals’ favorite) in bulk and sells to consumers in small quantities. The omena is normally packed in bags going at US$93.75 a bag. She has applied for US$700 to enable her to purchase more omena to sell during this dry season when the demand tends to be high.

loans.use: Purchase stock of fish (omena)

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Mrs. Khat Y., 62, is married with five children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home cooking food for her members, while her husband is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver, earning around $1/day of profit. Moreover, two of her children are blacksmiths, another one is a driver, and the rest of whom are unemployed. Mrs. Khat Y. hopes to use this loan to purchase cows to breed and the leftover of the money is to purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver

loans.name: Nazia

texts.en: I am Nazia B.. I am married and the mother of two children. My children are small and do not attend school at present. When they are old enough, I wish to enroll them in a good school. My husband is a scrap dealer. He travels to various nearby villages and collects different used items including spare parts, which he then sells in his own city. My husband does not have a proper conveyance to travel to nearby villages. He feels that his work can become very efficient if he buys a motorcycle for his business. Please lend him $200 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Betha

texts.en:
Bertha is a 38-year old entrepreneur who lives in Siaya, Kenya, with her husband and six children. She has also trained as a community health worker to provide home-based care to people living with HIV/AIDS in her area. The cereal selling business that she initiated in 1993 was doing quite well until about a year ago when her husband was laid off and she became the sole income earner in her household. To supplement her income, Bertha set up a fruit and vegetable stand near her home.

Her hard work, determination, and excellent skills have led to her success. Her profits pay the household expenses as well as secondary school fees for two of her children. Bertha plans to use the funds from her next loan of US$800 to buy twenty sacks of grains, particularly maize. As the price of this staple food is currently low, she will buy in bulk now to sell at a larger profit later.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of grains, particularly maize.

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Mrs. Khat Y., 62, is a widow and lives with her five kids in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home cooking food for her members, while one of her children is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver, earning around $1/day of profit. , two of whom are blacksmiths, another one is a driver, and the rest of whom is unemployed. Mrs. Khat Y. hopes to use this loan to purchase cows to breed and the leftover of the money is to purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif is a 24-year-old farmer who sells dairy products to the local people and bazaar traders in the southern region of Saatli. He lives with his parents in their small house. His parents are pensioners (retired), and selling milk and yogurt is the only financial source for his family. He needs more funds to expand his business and to become the owner of a big farm. But his business brings him income only for covering family needs and his and parents' medicine. To broad his business he decided to purchase four calves to breed cattle for meat production. Meat is in very high demand on Azerbaijan and people have meat at every single meal. For this purpose he applied for 1200 USD to purchase four calves for estimated cost each of 300 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase four calves

loans.name: Naziran

texts.en: I am Naziran B. from the small city of Arifwala, Pakistan. I am 40, married, and the mother of seven. My husband owns a donkey cart, which he uses to transport goods from one place to another on order. One of my sons operates a vegetable business, and now he wishes to expand it. Please lend him $175 for this purpose. I have been a member of my loan group for the past year, and I have always repaid my loan installments on time and in a responsible manner.

loans.use: Expand vegetable business.

loans.name: Teresa Venâncio

texts.pt:
Teresa Venâncio S. is 39 years old. She is a single mother of 3 children. They live in Corumana, a district of Moamba in Maputo. She joined the program in November 2006. Her first loan was of 4.000mt. She sells fish in Corumana and Malhapswene. She is in the 3rd cycle of the credit program and is requesting a loan of 10.000mt to be repaid in 6 months. Teresa plans on buying and reselling goats with this loan.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Teresa Venâncio S. tem 39 anos de idade e é mãe solteira de 3 filhos.Vive em Corumana no distrito da Moamba em Maputo. Entrou para o progrma em Novembro de 2006 com um empréstimo inicial de 4.000MT. Vende peixe em Corumana e também em Malhapswene. Está no terceiro ciclo de empréstimo, tendo se comportado bem nos ciclos anteriores.Vai tomar 10.000MT para pagar em 6 meses e pretende investir o valor do presente empréstimo na compra e venda de cabritos.

loans.use: To buy Goats

loans.name: Qarib

texts.ru:
Qarib D. was born in 1962 in the city of Karakojunlu, Ahsun region. He is married and has two children. He has been in the business of raising cattle for the past 5 years. At the beginning he had only one cow and it was an insufficient amount to start a business. Qarib came to Normico. The credit he obtained allowed him to purchase several sheep. Currently he needs another loan to purchase several additional cows.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Дунямалыев Кариб родился 1962 году в село Каракоюнлу Ахсуниского района.Семейный , имеет двоих детей. Пять лет подряд занимается скотоводством. Сначала было всего одно корова и этого не хватало чтобы сделать свой бизнес. Кариб обратился в Нормикро Ахсуниский филиал. Взяв кредит купил еще несколько овец. Теперь ему нужен еще кредит чтобы купить несколько коров.

loans.use: To increase the quantity animals

loans.name: Araz

texts.en: Araz is a 42-year-old trader who owns a shop where he sells spare parts for cars, and he rents a small garage. He lives with his wife and 3 children in a southern village of the Saatli region. He has seven years of experience. Since that time, with the income he has earned he built his own garage and continues running his business in new place. He has a large number of customers because Araz can fix the spare parts that he sells. Customers are very satisfied with his work. However, more and more foreign cars fill the car market, and spare parts for them are very expensive. Araz is afraid he could lose his permanent customers because more and more people are selling their Russian cars and buying foreign ones. He urgently needs to diversify the products he sells. For this purpose he has applied for 1200 USD to purchase newer, modern spare parts.

loans.use: Going to purchase modern spare parts.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Dadadjon

texts.ru:
Dadadjon works on the regional market. The goods are delivered to him from the city. He is married and has 3 children. He has been working on the market for the past 8 years. He came to MicroInvest in 2007 asking for a credit that will allow him to increase the size of his business.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Дададжон работает на рынке своего района, ему привозят товар с города. Он семьянин, имеет троих детей и на рынке он около 8 лет. В "Микроинвест" он обратился в 2007 году, что бы расширить бизнес.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries and resale on the market

loans.name: Jaime Fernando

texts.pt:
Jaime Fernando H. is 27 years old, he lives with his wife and 2 children. He joined the credit program in June 2007, and his first loan was of 6.000mt. He sells feed in the Xiquelene market in Maputo. Jaime is requesting a loan of 12.000mt to be repaid in 5 months. He wants to increase his inventory and build a place to store his product.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Jaime Fernando H. tem 27 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é pai de 2 filhos. Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2007 com um empréstimo de 6.000MT.Vende uma variedade de rações em sacos e em canecas no mercado de Xiquelene em Maputo.Vai tomar 12.000MT para pagar em 5 meses com vista a aumentar o stock de ração uma vez que está a construir um depósito para comprar ração em grandes quantidades.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Mrs. Chey K., 35, is married and lives with her husband and two little kids in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.  To support the household, she and her husband work raising poultry and also work as brokers buying yams from growers and selling them for a profit.  This activity enables them to generate collectively about $2/day of profit.  This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase more yams and to invest in their business.

loans.use: To purchase more yams and invest in their business.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Mrs. Sun C., age 34, runs a small booth selling duck eggs, earning around $5 each day of profit. Her husband is a fisherman, making less than $1 per day. They have two children, one who is a student and one who is unemployed. She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase more ducks to breed for eggs to sell in the market.

loans.use: To purchase ducks to produce more eggs to sell in the market.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early.

Thanks to your support of entrepreneurs like Sun Channy, small businesses from around the world have access to low-interest capital to help with their operations.

We hope that you will continue loaning on Kiva through CREDIT MFI in the future. 

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang.
Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Zeynab

texts.ru:
Zeynab M. was born in 1984. She lives in the city of Karakoiunlu, in the Ahsuin region. She is married and has 2 children. The first time she came to Normico was two years ago. The $200 credit allowed her family to purchase several cows. This year they came to Normico for the second time in order to obtain a credit for $600 that will allow them to increase the size of their business.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Магеррамова Зейнаб.1984 года рождения.Родилась и проживает в село Каракойунлу Ахсуинского района. Замужем имеет двоих детей. В первый раз она обратилась в Нормикро Ахсуинского филиала два года тому назад. Получив кредит нак сумму четыресто долларов их семья купила несколько коров. В этом году семья вторично обратилась в Нормикро Ахсуинского филиала чтобу повторно взять кредит на сумму шестьсот долларов,чтобы расширить свой бизнес.

loans.use: To increase the quantity animals
